attributes.title: Does Concurrent Enrollment Program Improve Time-To-Degree and Wages? A Study to Inform the Scale-up of Colorado's Concurrent Enrollment Programs Act
attributes.description: This study serves to inform Colorado’s understanding of concurrent enrollment as a driver of efficiency in getting to an on-time postsecondary credential. High school students that participate in the Colorado's concurrent enrollment program may enroll tuition-free in postsecondary courses and earn college credits that are transferable to any Colorado public university.

q1.value: Does Concurrent Enrollment Program Improve Time-To-Degree and Earnings?

q2.value: Kristin Klopfenstein, Pamela Rose Buckley, Philip Pendergast

q3.value: This study serves to inform Colorado’s understanding of concurrent enrollment as a driver of efficiency in getting to an on-time postsecondary credential. Launched in the 2009-10 school year after passage of Colorado HB09-1319 and SB09-285, the Concurrent Enrollment Programs Act created Colorado’s present program, defined as “the simultaneous enrollment of a qualified student in a local education provider and in one or more postsecondary courses, including academic or career and technical education courses, which may include course work related to apprenticeship programs or internship programs, at an institution of higher education.” High school students that participate in the state’s concurrent enrollment program may enroll tuition-free in postsecondary courses and earn college credits that are transferable to any Colorado public university.

q4.value:
Hypothesis #1: Concurrent enrollment will improve the rate of earning a credential within two years of expected high school graduation among youth who matriculate to a two-year college within one year of expected high school graduation relative to similarly situated youth who did not participate in concurrent enrollment. 

Hypothesis #2: Concurrent enrollment will improve the rate of earning a four-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation date among youth who (a) matriculate to a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year college or (b) matriculate directly to a four-year college within one year of expected high school graduation relative to similarly situated youth who did not participate in concurrent enrollment.

Hypothesis #3: Concurrent enrollment will improve earnings five years after expected high school graduation date among youth who matriculate to college within one year of their expected high school graduation date relative to similarly situated youth who did not participate in concurrent enrollment.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present research is structured using a two-staged quasi-experimental propensity score matching design. Students who attempted one more concurrent enrollment courses funded through the state’s program and matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduate date (treatment) are matched to students who matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduate date but had no exposure to concurrent enrollment (control).

q9.value:
The study has a quasi-experimental design utilizing two-stage nearest neighbor propensity score matching to identify an observationally similar comparison group. Three decisions are included in determining the matching strategy:

1.	Distance metric  
a.	Computation of all pairwise distances between treatment and control 
b.	With propensity score matching (PSM), distance measures are calculated using logistic regression rather than exact matches on covariates
c.	Distance of 0 implied units are identical on all observed covariates
d.	Use “MatchIt” R package

2.	Matching strategy 
a.	Use a 1:1 ratio (yielding equal control and treatment group sizes) 
b.	Nearest neighbor

3.	Matching without replacement is conducted

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: This project is a retrospective study relying on secondary analysis of historical data. Matching, independent and dependent variables are measured using administrative data that originates from four sources: (1) Colorado Department of Education (CDE) – secondary achievement and sociodemographic data; (2) Colorado Department of Higher Education (CDHE) – postsecondary completion data for attendance at in-state colleges; (3) National Student Clearinghouse (NSC) – postsecondary data for completion at out-of-state colleges; and (4) Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) – unemployment insurance (UI) earnings quarterly data. The data used in this study are therefore administrative, collected by Colorado state agencies as part of their regular job duties.

question.value:
Population of Subjects: 

This longitudinal, cohort-based study follows students who graduated from Colorado high schools between 2010-2011 and 2013-2014. Cohorts are designated by the school year in which students were in 11th grade because while the 2009 legislation designated all high school students as eligible to participate in concurrent enrollment courses in grades 9 through 12, most concurrent enrollment courses in Colorado are offered to 11th and 12th grade students. Statewide, 32 percent of all 11th and 12th graders in public high schools in Colorado participated in concurrent enrollment in 2016-17. This study therefore involves cohorts of 11th grade students across five academic years, starting in the fall of 2009 through the fall of 2012. Given the data available for the period of the present study, four cohorts are constructed – starting when students were in 11th grade and defined by their expected high school graduation year. TABLE 1 presents the study’s cohorts.

Inclusion Rules:

Evaluation specific inclusion criteria include: (1) Must have 2008-09 baseline school-level data; (2) Must be a traditional student/school in which individuals earn a high school degree (or GED), typically done in four years (that is, the expected high school graduation date is in four years) because this is how most students experience concurrent enrollment education in Colorado. The definition of “traditional school” includes charter and innovation schools that offered high school degrees; and (3) Must have a school sample size of 11th and 12th grade students that includes 10 or more students (per cohort), as “treatment” is defined first at the school level and then at the student level, and investigators need a minimum number of students who were eligible to take concurrent enrollment.

Exclusion Rules:

Evaluation specific exclusion criteria include:

(1) Students who attended an Early College High School (ECHS) during the period of the study – Students attend a Colorado state board-approved high school that, through partnerships with institutions of higher education, enable them to earn 60 credits and an associate degree (or a specified number of college credits). The program is funded through the annual K-12 school finance act/PPR and is therefore exempt from Colorado’s concurrent enrollment act. 

(2) ASCENT students – 13th year of school. ASCENT stands for Accelerating Students through Concurrent ENrollmenT. Students who have completed at least 12 credit hours of postsecondary course prior to completion of their 12th grade year may be eligible for the ASCENT Program. They remain students in their Local Education Provider (LEP) for one year following their 12th grade year, and the LEP receives ASCENT specific per-pupil state funding that it uses to pay their college tuition at the resident community college rate. Students receive their high-school diplomas at the end of their ASCENT year. 

(3) Other dual – students taking a course outside Colorado’s state-funded concurrent (or “dual”) enrollment program. Programs identified by the state of Colorado as “other” high school concurrent enrollment programs are administered directly by postsecondary institutions and do not fall under the state’s statutory definition of concurrent enrollment. Students can receive college-level credit through these other programs, but they and their families may be required to pay for courses. Additionally, these completed courses are not required to transfer and/or apply to programs of study at other Colorado public institutions of higher education (Colorado Department of Higher Education, & Colorado Department of Education, 2018).

Recruitment

This project involves the same matched sample constructed for a study funded by the Institute of Education Sciences titled “The Outcomes and Return on Investment of Concurrent Enrollment in Colorado: A Researcher-Practitioner Partnership to Improve Postsecondary Access and Success” (Award R305H170049; PIs K. Poast, Colorado Department of Higher Education, P. Buckley, University of Colorado Boulder). The IES-funded study is registered with the Registry of Efficacy and Effectiveness Studies (REES), and can be located here: https://sreereg.icpsr.umich.edu/framework/pdf/index.php?id=2232. The present study extends previous research to examine time-to-degree and earnings. 

The treatment is defined as 11th and 12th grade students who attempted concurrent enrollment credits while attending a school with “more” concurrent enrollment opportunities. Treatment students are compared to a business-as-usual comparison group of 11th and 12th grade students who did not attempt any concurrent enrollment credits while attending otherwise similar high schools offering “fewer” concurrent enrollment opportunities. Groups are identified at the school-level using the state median number of concurrent enrollment credits attempted in 2008-09 (the baseline year), with “more” opportunities represented by schools at or above the state median and “fewer” reflecting schools below the state median. Baseline equivalence at the student level is established using Hedges g (with pooled standard deviations) for continuous variables and Cox’s d for dichotomous measures. Research groups are formed as follows:

1. As a first step, treatment and control schools are crudely matched on three school-level variables: a) free and reduced lunch status (FRL; a proxy for income in education research), b) ninth grade reading achievement, and c) college-going rates. In addition, high schools are exactly matched on urbanicity (urban/suburban vs. rural). For reference only (since baseline equivalence is formally established at the student level), treatment and comparison schools are well-matched on college-going rate (g = 0.10) and student achievement (g = 0.01), and less well-matched on FRL percent (g = 0.50).

2. For each sample, if baseline equivalence is not achieved between all students attempting concurrent enrollment credits at the matched treatment schools (treatment students) and all students who did not attempt concurrent enrollment credits at the matched comparison schools (comparison students), 1:1, nearest neighbor propensity score matching without replacement will be used to match students across conditions by cohort, FRL status, gender, ninth grade reading achievement, minority status, and English language learner (ELL) status. Consistent with What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) standards as outlined in the Transition to College Review Protocol, baseline equivalence of better than 0.25 standard deviations will be established on ninth grade standardized reading scores and FRL status. All matching variables will also be included in analytic models. 

In summary, treatment and comparison students are never drawn from the same school. By selecting comparison students from schools offering “fewer” concurrent enrollment opportunities, the potential confound from the self-selection of comparison students out of concurrent enrollment courses is minimized. Overall, this two-stage matching process will result in a comparison group that was very well matched to the treatment group at both school and student levels.

Footnotes: 

(1) Exact matching at the school level is conducted on “urbanicity” (i.e., whether the school was rural or urban/suburban) to arrive at results for common support because: (1) Groups were balanced before matching on all school-level variables except “Urbanicity”; (2) Concurrent enrollment access is determined at the school level and urbanicity strongly predicts concurrent enrollment offerings. Rural schools tend to lean heavily on concurrent enrollment because they do not have the student numbers to support alternative programs like Advanced Placement (AP) and International Baccalaureate (IB). Given this structural difference between rural and non-rural schools, we matched “concurrent enrollment rich” rural schools only with “concurrent enrollment poor” rural schools and “concurrent enrollment rich” non-rural schools only with “concurrent enrollment poor” non-rural schools.

(2) Sequential matching process of schools first, then students within those schools. The logic for doing so is because in conducting a quasi-experimental design (QED), the matching process must address issues of access and opportunity (which is a structural issue), as investigators theorize that opportunity is correlated with whether schools offer concurrent enrollment courses.

Study Timeline:

This project is a retrospective study relying on secondary analysis of historical data. Cohorts of 11th grade students are followed across five academic years, starting in the fall of 2009 through the fall of 2012. In terms of outcomes, postsecondary data encompass academic year (AY) 2011-2012 through AY 2015- 2016. Unemployment insurance (UI) data is based on calendar year and quarter. For this study, earnings (UI) data encompass calendar year 2012 through 2018.

q13.value:
Postsecondary Outcomes:

As a result of the two-stage matching process followed for this study, the initial matched sample includes 25,262 students (12,631 in treatment and 12,631 in control) nested in 172 schools (86 in treatment and 86 in control) that are used to examine matriculation. We then obtain a second matched sample, using the same variables and effect size metrics described earlier, of 13,830 students (6,915 in treatment and 6,915 in control) in 168 schools (84 treatment, 84 control) who matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduation date to examine college completion and earnings. These 13,830 students are the sample for the present study. TABLE 2 presents the sample size (by cohort and overall) for the matched sample. Cohort is based on expected high school graduation (so the 2010-11 cohort would be in college in 2011-12, and so on). In sum, the matched sample examining postsecondary outcomes includes 13,830 students who graduated from a Colorado public high school and matriculated to a postsecondary institution (either in-state or out-of-state) within one year of their expected high school graduation date.  

The sample size for each postsecondary outcome varies depending on the number of years for which postsecondary available for each cohort (see TABLE 3). That is, cohorts one (expected high school graduation in 2010-2011) and two (expected high school graduation in 2011-2012) have up to five and four years of potential postsecondary data, respectively – thus all models assessing postsecondary outcomes will include these two cohorts. In contrast, cohort 4 (expected high school graduation in 2013-2014) has two years of potential postsecondary data and therefore this cohort can only be included in one of the models analyzing postsecondary outcomes for this study.

Earnings Outcomes:

The matched sample of 13,830 students that matriculated to college within one year of expected high school graduation is also used to assess earnings. The Colorado Department of Higher Education (CDHE) will link students in the matched sample with students in the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) dataset using social security number (SSN). Important limitations of this sample include: (1) Only students for whom CDHE can find unemployment insurance (UI) data in the CDLE dataset can be included in the analysis; (2) If a college graduate leaves Colorado for work, they do not show up in the CDLE dataset; (3) If an industry or particular employer does not conform with unemployment insurance (UI), CDLE will not have UI data for workers in these industries. This includes, but is not limited to, some who work in agricultural employment, military and federal civilian employment, railroad employment and self-employment, as these workers are not included in Colorado’s UI database.

In sum, the sample evaluating earnings includes students with an SSN from the matched sample found in the CDLE unemployment insurance (UI) database who are employed in Colorado. The UI data, however, do not include all people in the labor force, omitting some in agricultural employment, military and federal civilian employment, railroad employment and those who are self-employed.

On average, the match rate of student-level postsecondary outcomes to student-level UI data is around 50 percent (though this match rate might vary a bit depending on the year, degree level, and program, as reported by CDHE). Thus, if the match rate hovers around 50 percent statewide, we should expect to find earnings outcomes for roughly half the matched sample (or 6,915 students). See estimated sample size by cohort in TABLE 4.

Like the postsecondary outcomes, the sample size for each earnings outcome varies depending on the number of years for which unemployment insurance (UI) data are available for each cohort (see TABLE 5). That is, UI data pulled within 5 years of expected high school graduation date are available for cohorts 1 (expected high school graduation in 2010-2011), 2 (expected high school graduation in 2011-2012) and 3 (expected high school graduation in 2012-2013); this model will therefore only include these three cohorts. In contrast, all four cohorts will be included in the model assessing earnings within 3 years of expected high school graduation date.

Sample Size Summary:

TABLE 6 provides a summary of each research question, data source, and students’ expected educational progression during the periods covered by the present study. Included in Table 6 is a breakdown of the confirmatory vs. exploratory research questions along with an explanation of which cohorts will be included in each model given the years for which data are available from each data source.

q14.value:
In the study pre-registered with REES (described elsewhere in this document), the initial matched sample includes 25,262 students (12,631 in treatment and 12,631 in control) nested in 172 schools (86 in treatment and 86 in control) that are used to examine matriculation to college within one year of expected high school graduation date. We then obtain a second matched sample of students who matriculated to college within one year of high school, using the same variables and effect size metrics described earlier, of 13,830 students nested in 168 schools (84 treatment, 84 control). This second matched sample will be used for the present study. 

Power analyses conducted in PowerUp! [1] and Optimal Design [2] had these conservative assumptions: 2-level CRT; 168 schools at baseline with an average cluster size of n=82 students; .10 and .30 for the proportion of variance accounted for by level 2 and level 1 covariates; p < .05; and a conservative estimate of ICCs r =.10 for college completion outcomes. Based on the literature on designing a study at the secondary level that includes binary outcomes [3, 4, 5, 6] and intervention studies that reported effect sizes for postsecondary outcomes including college completion [7, 8, 9], ICCs for the postsecondary outcomes range from .02-.10 and effect sizes typically range from small to small-medium (Cohen’s d = .20 - .29). We will have power of .80 to achieve a minimum detectable effect size (MDES) of d = .043 for primary outcomes, indicating that the study is sufficiently powered to detect a small intervention effect size at a minimum at the posttest. Studies on earnings outcomes for school-based interventions implemented at the secondary level are sparse. Thus, using the same metrics described above, but expecting half the sample size (86 schools with an average cluster size of n=80) due to the linking of postsecondary datasets to earnings data sets (described elsewhere in this document), we will have a power of .80 to achieve a MDES of d = .061. This bodes well for the evaluation’s ability to identify an effect for college completion and earnings outcomes, should one exist, as these minimum detectible effect sizes are smaller than the anticipated impacts of the intervention. In addition, the power of the full estimation models is expected to be enhanced by including control variables that account for a meaningful proportion of variance in the outcomes.

question.value:
Postsecondary Outcome Variables: 

Students enroll in public two-year community colleges to pursue a variety of goals. Some want to learn specific skills but not necessarily earn a credential. Others may want to obtain an industry-recognized certificate, take remedial courses to prepare for further postsecondary education, or take courses to prepare for transfer to a four-year college or university. In short, the goal for many community college students is not an associate degree, and many who earn an associate degree will seek four-year degrees. Considering these factors, college success will be assessed using different measures (each analyzed as a separate model): 

(1) Earning a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 2-year institution, and will not include students who start at a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date.

(2) Earning a four-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution.

(3) Earning a four-year degree within three years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution.

Earnings Outcome Variables:

Both the Colorado Department of Higher Education (CDHE) and Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) data sets provide social security numbers (SSN), which allows the departments to link data sets. However, the Colorado Department of Education (CDE) data set does not contain SSN. Thus, the only opportunity to identify earnings outcomes for secondary students in this study is for cases in which the student matriculated to college. For this reason, the earnings analysis is limited to students who attempted at least one postsecondary course. The analysis will therefore examine:

(1) Earnings five years after students’ expected high school graduation date. This analysis will include all students in the matched sample for which a SSN is located in the unemployment insurance (UI) data. Quarterly data will be summed for the fifth calendar year after a student’s expected high school graduation date. For example, for students whose expected high school graduation date was May 2012, their earnings will be summed from Q1 2017 to Q4 2017.

(2) Earnings three years after expected high school graduation date for those who initially matriculated to a 2-year college. This analysis will be limited to only those students from the matched sample who matriculated to a 2-year college and did not transfer to a 4-year college. Quarterly data will be summed for the third calendar year after a student’s expected high school graduation date. For example, for students whose expected high school date was May 2012, their earnings their earnings will be summed from Q1 2015 to Q4 2015.

Footnote: Wages are pay for a set amount of time (e.g. dollars paid per hour) and are not available in unemployment insurance (UI) data. Earnings are wage*hours worked, which is what is reported in UI data. An important limitation of this work is that whether earnings are higher for treatment students (supposing the research hypothesis holds) because the wage is higher or because more hours are worked cannot be determined.

Measured variables:

•	Quarterly earnings (3 and 5-year)
•	Postsecondary enrollment institution type (2 vs. 4 year)
•	Degree completion (2 and 4 year)
•	English language learner status
•	Race/Ethnicity
•	Urbanicity
•	Gender
•	9th grade reading standardized test scores
•	Condition

Statistical Models:

Three separate confirmatory analyses will be run, each on the sample of students who matriculate to college within one year of their expected high school graduation date. Outcomes include 1) completion of a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date, 2) completion of a 4-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation, and 3) earnings in the fifth calendar year after expected high school graduation. For each model, multi-level regression models will be employed. Mixed effects logistic regression models will be used to estimate the odds of on-time or early college completion, while linear regression will be used to model earnings in the fifth year after expected high school graduation for matched students in the treatment group who matriculate to college compared to matched students in the control group who matriculate to college, while adjusting for school-level clustering (by including random intercepts for high schools) and student-level characteristics. Student-level controls will include ELL status, urbanicity, income, ethnicity, gender, ninth grade reading scores, and cohort in all models. We will use the Bonferroni method of adjustment for multiple comparisons when running each model.

q20.value:
• Free-Reduced Lunch (FRL) status = 1 if low-income, 0 if not low-income
• Underrepresented minority (Ethnicity), 1 if all other, 0 if White or Asian
• Gender, 1 if female, 0 if male
• English Language Learner (ELL) status, 1 if an English learner, 0 if not an English learner
• Urbanicity, 1 if rural, 0 if urban/suburban
• 9th grade reading score (entered as grand-mean centered)
• Condition, 1 if treatment, 0 if control
• Credential/degree attainment, a categorical variable equaling 0 if no credential was earned, 1 if a credential or 2-year degree, 2 if 4-year degree 
• Immediate postsecondary enrollment institution type, 0 if 2-year college, 1 if 4-year college
• School-level random intercept based on school IDs (not transformed)

q21.value: Bonferroni-adjusted Significance Levels: * p-value less than .0125; ** p-value less than .0025; *** p-value less than .0025, two tailed tests for the overall evaluation.

q22.value: The sample will exclude treatment and potential comparison youth with missing data on the key matching variables and, for the earnings questions, earnings outcomes. Students missing credential completion outcomes are assumed to have not completed a credential and are coded as 0 for the outcome. Furthermore, if baseline equivalence is not achieved on key matching variables in the full analytic sample, treatment youth with the least similar matched comparisons will be omitted from the sample until baseline equivalence is achieved.

q23.value: Patterns in missingness will be examined to inform generalization. Listwise deletion will be used to remove participants from a given analysis if outcome or key matching variables are missing.

q24.value:
Separate, more exploratory tests of moderating factors are planned for each of the three confirmatory outcomes by including interaction effects between concurrent enrollment participation and (1) race/ethnicity; (2) free-and-reduced lung (FRL; income) status; (3) gender; and (4) ninth grade reading test scores. 

Another exploratory analysis will include earning a four-year degree within three years of expected high school graduation date. Like the previously described confirmatory model (earning a 4-year degree within four years), this analytic sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution. The outcome is earning a 4-year degree in three years after expected high school graduation as opposed to four years. Consistent with the 4-year degree in four years model, this analysis will also include moderation tests by including interaction terms between race/ethnicity, FRL status, gender and ninth grade reading test scores.

Investigators will also run an exploratory analysis examining matriculation to a 2-year college within one year of expected high school graduation date to determine if there are different impacts of concurrent enrollment on earnings three years after expected high school graduation date. This analysis will take the same form as the previously-described model, with the analytic sample only including students who enrolled in 2-year institutions within the first year of expected high school graduation and omitting those who started at a 2-year college and transferred to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. The outcome in these models will be earnings three years after expected high school graduation rather than year five earnings. As with the 5-year earnings outcome, the analysis will include exploratory, moderation tests by including interaction terms between race/ethnicity, FRL status, gender, ninth grade reading test scores, and credential attainment and treatment.

q25.value:
Baseline Equivalence of Groups 

Following the matching procedure described in previous sections, baseline equivalence will be re-examined for the samples used to evaluate postsecondary outcomes (i.e., earning a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date; earning a four-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation date, within three years). Baseline equivalence tests and possibly matching for earnings outcome student-level samples will also be re-done until baseline equivalence is achieved. For each baseline equivalence test (which will be conducted at the student-level), the same variables will be used as will the same metrics, and the same procedures will be followed as those for the postsecondary outcomes. Thus, for both the postsecondary and earnings outcomes, baseline equivalence will be achieved if the standardized difference between the two groups is .25 or less for student-level 9th grade reading scores and income. 

Correspondence with Ethical Standards for Research

The research protocol has been reviewed and approved by the University of Colorado at Boulder’s Institutional Review Board (IRB). 

Evaluation Deliverables 

The Principal Investigator shall send all deliverables listed below to all members of the partnership group, including representatives from the state agencies providing data. These materials shall be transmitted on schedule electronically. As needed, the evaluator will be available to answer questions at partnership meetings regarding these deliverables.

All Outcomes Reports, as well as any Progress Reports requested, shall also be shared with any additional philanthropists who fund the cost of the evaluation.

All deliverables listed below will be completely de-identified; at no time will identifying information on any youth, including names, birthdates, ID numbers or other identifying information, be included in any of the below deliverables.

Deliverable 1 - Confirmation of IRB Approval: No later than November 15, 2019 the evaluator shall confirm in writing for the partnership group that the University of Colorado at Boulder’s Institutional Review Board has approved the evaluation.

Deliverable 2 - Final Outcomes Report: By May 25, 2020, the evaluator shall release to the partnership group a full Outcomes Report that: (1) Follows the registered analysis plan. (2) Details findings with respect to the intervention’s impact on postsecondary and earnings outcomes. (3) Includes clear, easily understandable summaries regarding any statistically significant differences with respect to Outcomes achieved across the Treatment and Control Groups. (4) Addresses any other meaningful differences between the Treatment and Control Groups and shows how the evaluation addressed these differences. (5) Describes any substantial factors that may have complicated or obscured the evaluation. (6) Highlights any critical findings from the evaluation that might suggest ways the impact of the program could be further strengthened. And (7) Further shows how the evaluation controlled for other relevant variables.

Postsecondary Outcomes:

As a result of the two-stage matching process followed for this study, the initial matched sample includes 25,262 students (12,631 in treatment and 12,631 in control) nested in 172 schools (86 in treatment and 86 in control) that are used to examine matriculation. We then obtain a second matched sample, using the same variables and effect size metrics described earlier, of 13,830 students (6,915 in treatment and 6,915 in control) in 168 schools (84 treatment, 84 control) who matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduation date to examine college completion and earnings. These 13,830 students are the sample for the present study. TABLE 2 presents the sample size (by cohort and overall) for the matched sample. Cohort is based on expected high school graduation (so the 2010-11 cohort would be in college in 2011-12, and so on). In sum, the matched sample examining postsecondary outcomes includes 13,830 students who graduated from a Colorado public high school and matriculated to a postsecondary institution (either in-state or out-of-state) within one year of their expected high school graduation date.  

The sample size for each postsecondary outcome varies depending on the number of years for which postsecondary available for each cohort (see TABLE 3). That is, cohorts one (expected high school graduation in 2010-2011) and two (expected high school graduation in 2011-2012) have up to five and four years of potential postsecondary data, respectively – thus all models assessing postsecondary outcomes will include these two cohorts. In contrast, cohort 4 (expected high school graduation in 2013-2014) has two years of potential postsecondary data and therefore this cohort can only be included in one of the models analyzing postsecondary outcomes for this study.

Earnings Outcomes:

The matched sample of 13,830 students that matriculated to college within one year of expected high school graduation is also used to assess earnings. The Colorado Department of Higher Education (CDHE) will link students in the matched sample with students in the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) dataset using social security number (SSN). Important limitations of this sample include: (1) Only students for whom CDHE can find unemployment insurance (UI) data in the CDLE dataset can be included in the analysis; (2) If a college graduate leaves Colorado for work, they do not show up in the CDLE dataset; (3) If an industry or particular employer does not conform with unemployment insurance (UI), CDLE will not have UI data for workers in these industries. This includes, but is not limited to, some who work in agricultural employment, military and federal civilian employment, railroad employment and self-employment, as these workers are not included in Colorado’s UI database.

In sum, the sample evaluating earnings includes students with an SSN from the matched sample found in the CDLE unemployment insurance (UI) database who are employed in Colorado. The UI data, however, do not include all people in the labor force, omitting some in agricultural employment, military and federal civilian employment, railroad employment and those who are self-employed.

On average, the match rate of student-level postsecondary outcomes to student-level UI data is around 50 percent (though this match rate might vary a bit depending on the year, degree level, and program, as reported by CDHE). Thus, if the match rate hovers around 50 percent statewide, we should expect to find earnings outcomes for roughly half the matched sample (or 6,915 students). See estimated sample size by cohort in TABLE 4.

Like the postsecondary outcomes, the sample size for each earnings outcome varies depending on the number of years for which unemployment insurance (UI) data are available for each cohort (see TABLE 5). That is, UI data pulled within 5 years of expected high school graduation date are available for cohorts 1 (expected high school graduation in 2010-2011), 2 (expected high school graduation in 2011-2012) and 3 (expected high school graduation in 2012-2013); this model will therefore only include these three cohorts. In contrast, all four cohorts will be included in the model assessing earnings within 3 years of expected high school graduation date.

Sample Size Summary:

TABLE 6 provides a summary of each research question, data source, and students’ expected educational progression during the periods covered by the present study. Included in Table 6 is a breakdown of the confirmatory vs. exploratory research questions along with an explanation of which cohorts will be included in each model given the years for which data are available from each data source.
registration_responses.q14:
In the study pre-registered with REES (described elsewhere in this document), the initial matched sample includes 25,262 students (12,631 in treatment and 12,631 in control) nested in 172 schools (86 in treatment and 86 in control) that are used to examine matriculation to college within one year of expected high school graduation date. We then obtain a second matched sample of students who matriculated to college within one year of high school, using the same variables and effect size metrics described earlier, of 13,830 students nested in 168 schools (84 treatment, 84 control). This second matched sample will be used for the present study. 

Power analyses conducted in PowerUp! [1] and Optimal Design [2] had these conservative assumptions: 2-level CRT; 168 schools at baseline with an average cluster size of n=82 students; .10 and .30 for the proportion of variance accounted for by level 2 and level 1 covariates; p < .05; and a conservative estimate of ICCs r =.10 for college completion outcomes. Based on the literature on designing a study at the secondary level that includes binary outcomes [3, 4, 5, 6] and intervention studies that reported effect sizes for postsecondary outcomes including college completion [7, 8, 9], ICCs for the postsecondary outcomes range from .02-.10 and effect sizes typically range from small to small-medium (Cohen’s d = .20 - .29). We will have power of .80 to achieve a minimum detectable effect size (MDES) of d = .043 for primary outcomes, indicating that the study is sufficiently powered to detect a small intervention effect size at a minimum at the posttest. Studies on earnings outcomes for school-based interventions implemented at the secondary level are sparse. Thus, using the same metrics described above, but expecting half the sample size (86 schools with an average cluster size of n=80) due to the linking of postsecondary datasets to earnings data sets (described elsewhere in this document), we will have a power of .80 to achieve a MDES of d = .061. This bodes well for the evaluation’s ability to identify an effect for college completion and earnings outcomes, should one exist, as these minimum detectible effect sizes are smaller than the anticipated impacts of the intervention. In addition, the power of the full estimation models is expected to be enhanced by including control variables that account for a meaningful proportion of variance in the outcomes.
registration_responses.q20:
• Free-Reduced Lunch (FRL) status = 1 if low-income, 0 if not low-income
• Underrepresented minority (Ethnicity), 1 if all other, 0 if White or Asian
• Gender, 1 if female, 0 if male
• English Language Learner (ELL) status, 1 if an English learner, 0 if not an English learner
• Urbanicity, 1 if rural, 0 if urban/suburban

registration_responses.q21: Bonferroni-adjusted Significance Levels: * p-value less than .0125; ** p-value less than .0025; *** p-value less than .0025, two tailed tests for the overall evaluation.
registration_responses.q22: The sample will exclude treatment and potential comparison youth with missing data on the key matching variables and, for the earnings questions, earnings outcomes. Students missing credential completion outcomes are assumed to have not completed a credential and are coded as 0 for the outcome. Furthermore, if baseline equivalence is not achieved on key matching variables in the full analytic sample, treatment youth with the least similar matched comparisons will be omitted from the sample until baseline equivalence is achieved.
registration_responses.q23: Patterns in missingness will be examined to inform generalization. Listwise deletion will be used to remove participants from a given analysis if outcome or key matching variables are missing.
registration_responses.q24:
Separate, more exploratory tests of moderating factors are planned for each of the three confirmatory outcomes by including interaction effects between concurrent enrollment participation and (1) race/ethnicity; (2) free-and-reduced lung (FRL; income) status; (3) gender; and (4) ninth grade reading test scores. 

Another exploratory analysis will include earning a four-year degree within three years of expected high school graduation date. Like the previously described confirmatory model (earning a 4-year degree within four years), this analytic sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution. The outcome is earning a 4-year degree in three years after expected high school graduation as opposed to four years. Consistent with the 4-year degree in four years model, this analysis will also include moderation tests by including interaction terms between race/ethnicity, FRL status, gender and ninth grade reading test scores.

Investigators will also run an exploratory analysis examining matriculation to a 2-year college within one year of expected high school graduation date to determine if there are different impacts of concurrent enrollment on earnings three years after expected high school graduation date. This analysis will take the same form as the previously-described model, with the analytic sample only including students who enrolled in 2-year institutions within the first year of expected high school graduation and omitting those who started at a 2-year college and transferred to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. The outcome in these models will be earnings three years after expected high school graduation rather than year five earnings. As with the 5-year earnings outcome, the analysis will include exploratory, moderation tests by including interaction terms between race/ethnicity, FRL status, gender, ninth grade reading test scores, and credential attainment and treatment.
registration_responses.q25:
Baseline Equivalence of Groups 

Following the matching procedure described in previous sections, baseline equivalence will be re-examined for the samples used to evaluate postsecondary outcomes (i.e., earning a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date; earning a four-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation date, within three years). Baseline equivalence tests and possibly matching for earnings outcome student-level samples will also be re-done until baseline equivalence is achieved. For each baseline equivalence test (which will be conducted at the student-level), the same variables will be used as will the same metrics, and the same procedures will be followed as those for the postsecondary outcomes. Thus, for both the postsecondary and earnings outcomes, baseline equivalence will be achieved if the standardized difference between the two groups is .25 or less for student-level 9th grade reading scores and income. 

Correspondence with Ethical Standards for Research

The research protocol has been reviewed and approved by the University of Colorado at Boulder’s Institutional Review Board (IRB). 

Evaluation Deliverables 

The Principal Investigator shall send all deliverables listed below to all members of the partnership group, including representatives from the state agencies providing data. These materials shall be transmitted on schedule electronically. As needed, the evaluator will be available to answer questions at partnership meetings regarding these deliverables.

All Outcomes Reports, as well as any Progress Reports requested, shall also be shared with any additional philanthropists who fund the cost of the evaluation.

All deliverables listed below will be completely de-identified; at no time will identifying information on any youth, including names, birthdates, ID numbers or other identifying information, be included in any of the below deliverables.

Deliverable 1 - Confirmation of IRB Approval: No later than November 15, 2019 the evaluator shall confirm in writing for the partnership group that the University of Colorado at Boulder’s Institutional Review Board has approved the evaluation.

Deliverable 2 - Final Outcomes Report: By May 25, 2020, the evaluator shall release to the partnership group a full Outcomes Report that: (1) Follows the registered analysis plan. (2) Details findings with respect to the intervention’s impact on postsecondary and earnings outcomes. (3) Includes clear, easily understandable summaries regarding any statistically significant differences with respect to Outcomes achieved across the Treatment and Control Groups. (4) Addresses any other meaningful differences between the Treatment and Control Groups and shows how the evaluation addressed these differences. (5) Describes any substantial factors that may have complicated or obscured the evaluation. (6) Highlights any critical findings from the evaluation that might suggest ways the impact of the program could be further strengthened. And (7) Further shows how the evaluation controlled for other relevant variables.
registration_responses.q8.question: The present research is structured using a two-staged quasi-experimental propensity score matching design. Students who attempted one more concurrent enrollment courses funded through the state’s program and matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduate date (treatment) are matched to students who matriculated to college within one year of their expected high school graduate date but had no exposure to concurrent enrollment (control).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Population of Subjects: 

This longitudinal, cohort-based study follows students who graduated from Colorado high schools between 2010-2011 and 2013-2014. Cohorts are designated by the school year in which students were in 11th grade because while the 2009 legislation designated all high school students as eligible to participate in concurrent enrollment courses in grades 9 through 12, most concurrent enrollment courses in Colorado are offered to 11th and 12th grade students. Statewide, 32 percent of all 11th and 12th graders in public high schools in Colorado participated in concurrent enrollment in 2016-17. This study therefore involves cohorts of 11th grade students across five academic years, starting in the fall of 2009 through the fall of 2012. Given the data available for the period of the present study, four cohorts are constructed – starting when students were in 11th grade and defined by their expected high school graduation year. TABLE 1 presents the study’s cohorts.

Inclusion Rules:

Evaluation specific inclusion criteria include: (1) Must have 2008-09 baseline school-level data; (2) Must be a traditional student/school in which individuals earn a high school degree (or GED), typically done in four years (that is, the expected high school graduation date is in four years) because this is how most students experience concurrent enrollment education in Colorado. The definition of “traditional school” includes charter and innovation schools that offered high school degrees; and (3) Must have a school sample size of 11th and 12th grade students that includes 10 or more students (per cohort), as “treatment” is defined first at the school level and then at the student level, and investigators need a minimum number of students who were eligible to take concurrent enrollment.

Exclusion Rules:

Evaluation specific exclusion criteria include:

(1) Students who attended an Early College High School (ECHS) during the period of the study – Students attend a Colorado state board-approved high school that, through partnerships with institutions of higher education, enable them to earn 60 credits and an associate degree (or a specified number of college credits). The program is funded through the annual K-12 school finance act/PPR and is therefore exempt from Colorado’s concurrent enrollment act. 

(2) ASCENT students – 13th year of school. ASCENT stands for Accelerating Students through Concurrent ENrollmenT. Students who have completed at least 12 credit hours of postsecondary course prior to completion of their 12th grade year may be eligible for the ASCENT Program. They remain students in their Local Education Provider (LEP) for one year following their 12th grade year, and the LEP receives ASCENT specific per-pupil state funding that it uses to pay their college tuition at the resident community college rate. Students receive their high-school diplomas at the end of their ASCENT year. 

(3) Other dual – students taking a course outside Colorado’s state-funded concurrent (or “dual”) enrollment program. Programs identified by the state of Colorado as “other” high school concurrent enrollment programs are administered directly by postsecondary institutions and do not fall under the state’s statutory definition of concurrent enrollment. Students can receive college-level credit through these other programs, but they and their families may be required to pay for courses. Additionally, these completed courses are not required to transfer and/or apply to programs of study at other Colorado public institutions of higher education (Colorado Department of Higher Education, & Colorado Department of Education, 2018).

Recruitment

This project involves the same matched sample constructed for a study funded by the Institute of Education Sciences titled “The Outcomes and Return on Investment of Concurrent Enrollment in Colorado: A Researcher-Practitioner Partnership to Improve Postsecondary Access and Success” (Award R305H170049; PIs K. Poast, Colorado Department of Higher Education, P. Buckley, University of Colorado Boulder). The IES-funded study is registered with the Registry of Efficacy and Effectiveness Studies (REES), and can be located here: https://sreereg.icpsr.umich.edu/framework/pdf/index.php?id=2232. The present study extends previous research to examine time-to-degree and earnings. 

The treatment is defined as 11th and 12th grade students who attempted concurrent enrollment credits while attending a school with “more” concurrent enrollment opportunities. Treatment students are compared to a business-as-usual comparison group of 11th and 12th grade students who did not attempt any concurrent enrollment credits while attending otherwise similar high schools offering “fewer” concurrent enrollment opportunities. Groups are identified at the school-level using the state median number of concurrent enrollment credits attempted in 2008-09 (the baseline year), with “more” opportunities represented by schools at or above the state median and “fewer” reflecting schools below the state median. Baseline equivalence at the student level is established using Hedges g (with pooled standard deviations) for continuous variables and Cox’s d for dichotomous measures. Research groups are formed as follows:

1. As a first step, treatment and control schools are crudely matched on three school-level variables: a) free and reduced lunch status (FRL; a proxy for income in education research), b) ninth grade reading achievement, and c) college-going rates. In addition, high schools are exactly matched on urbanicity (urban/suburban vs. rural). For reference only (since baseline equivalence is formally established at the student level), treatment and comparison schools are well-matched on college-going rate (g = 0.10) and student achievement (g = 0.01), and less well-matched on FRL percent (g = 0.50).

2. For each sample, if baseline equivalence is not achieved between all students attempting concurrent enrollment credits at the matched treatment schools (treatment students) and all students who did not attempt concurrent enrollment credits at the matched comparison schools (comparison students), 1:1, nearest neighbor propensity score matching without replacement will be used to match students across conditions by cohort, FRL status, gender, ninth grade reading achievement, minority status, and English language learner (ELL) status. Consistent with What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) standards as outlined in the Transition to College Review Protocol, baseline equivalence of better than 0.25 standard deviations will be established on ninth grade standardized reading scores and FRL status. All matching variables will also be included in analytic models. 

In summary, treatment and comparison students are never drawn from the same school. By selecting comparison students from schools offering “fewer” concurrent enrollment opportunities, the potential confound from the self-selection of comparison students out of concurrent enrollment courses is minimized. Overall, this two-stage matching process will result in a comparison group that was very well matched to the treatment group at both school and student levels.

Footnotes: 

(1) Exact matching at the school level is conducted on “urbanicity” (i.e., whether the school was rural or urban/suburban) to arrive at results for common support because: (1) Groups were balanced before matching on all school-level variables except “Urbanicity”; (2) Concurrent enrollment access is determined at the school level and urbanicity strongly predicts concurrent enrollment offerings. Rural schools tend to lean heavily on concurrent enrollment because they do not have the student numbers to support alternative programs like Advanced Placement (AP) and International Baccalaureate (IB). Given this structural difference between rural and non-rural schools, we matched “concurrent enrollment rich” rural schools only with “concurrent enrollment poor” rural schools and “concurrent enrollment rich” non-rural schools only with “concurrent enrollment poor” non-rural schools.

(2) Sequential matching process of schools first, then students within those schools. The logic for doing so is because in conducting a quasi-experimental design (QED), the matching process must address issues of access and opportunity (which is a structural issue), as investigators theorize that opportunity is correlated with whether schools offer concurrent enrollment courses.

Study Timeline:

This project is a retrospective study relying on secondary analysis of historical data. Cohorts of 11th grade students are followed across five academic years, starting in the fall of 2009 through the fall of 2012. In terms of outcomes, postsecondary data encompass academic year (AY) 2011-2012 through AY 2015- 2016. Unemployment insurance (UI) data is based on calendar year and quarter. For this study, earnings (UI) data encompass calendar year 2012 through 2018.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Postsecondary Outcome Variables: 

Students enroll in public two-year community colleges to pursue a variety of goals. Some want to learn specific skills but not necessarily earn a credential. Others may want to obtain an industry-recognized certificate, take remedial courses to prepare for further postsecondary education, or take courses to prepare for transfer to a four-year college or university. In short, the goal for many community college students is not an associate degree, and many who earn an associate degree will seek four-year degrees. Considering these factors, college success will be assessed using different measures (each analyzed as a separate model): 

(1) Earning a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 2-year institution, and will not include students who start at a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date.

(2) Earning a four-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution.

(3) Earning a four-year degree within three years of expected high school graduation date. This sample will include students who initially enroll in a 4-year institution. It also will include those who enroll in a 2-year college and transfer to a 4-year institution within 2 years of their expected high school graduation date. In addition, the sample will include those who initially enroll in a 2-year college, earn a credential, and then enroll immediately in a 4-year institution.

Earnings Outcome Variables:

Both the Colorado Department of Higher Education (CDHE) and Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) data sets provide social security numbers (SSN), which allows the departments to link data sets. However, the Colorado Department of Education (CDE) data set does not contain SSN. Thus, the only opportunity to identify earnings outcomes for secondary students in this study is for cases in which the student matriculated to college. For this reason, the earnings analysis is limited to students who attempted at least one postsecondary course. The analysis will therefore examine:

(1) Earnings five years after students’ expected high school graduation date. This analysis will include all students in the matched sample for which a SSN is located in the unemployment insurance (UI) data. Quarterly data will be summed for the fifth calendar year after a student’s expected high school graduation date. For example, for students whose expected high school graduation date was May 2012, their earnings will be summed from Q1 2017 to Q4 2017.

(2) Earnings three years after expected high school graduation date for those who initially matriculated to a 2-year college. This analysis will be limited to only those students from the matched sample who matriculated to a 2-year college and did not transfer to a 4-year college. Quarterly data will be summed for the third calendar year after a student’s expected high school graduation date. For example, for students whose expected high school date was May 2012, their earnings their earnings will be summed from Q1 2015 to Q4 2015.

Footnote: Wages are pay for a set amount of time (e.g. dollars paid per hour) and are not available in unemployment insurance (UI) data. Earnings are wage*hours worked, which is what is reported in UI data. An important limitation of this work is that whether earnings are higher for treatment students (supposing the research hypothesis holds) because the wage is higher or because more hours are worked cannot be determined.

Measured variables:

•	Quarterly earnings (3 and 5-year)
•	Postsecondary enrollment institution type (2 vs. 4 year)
•	Degree completion (2 and 4 year)
•	English language learner status
•	Race/Ethnicity
•	Urbanicity
•	Gender
•	9th grade reading standardized test scores
•	Condition
registration_responses.q19.question:
Statistical Models:

Three separate confirmatory analyses will be run, each on the sample of students who matriculate to college within one year of their expected high school graduation date. Outcomes include 1) completion of a credential within two years of expected high school graduation date, 2) completion of a 4-year degree within four years of expected high school graduation, and 3) earnings in the fifth calendar year after expected high school graduation. For each model, multi-level regression models will be employed. Mixed effects logistic regression models will be used to estimate the odds of on-time or early college completion, while linear regression will be used to model earnings in the fifth year after expected high school graduation for matched students in the treatment group who matriculate to college compared to matched students in the control group who matriculate to college, while adjusting for school-level clustering (by including random intercepts for high schools) and student-level characteristics. Student-level controls will include ELL status, urbanicity, income, ethnicity, gender, ninth grade reading scores, and cohort in all models. We will use the Bonferroni method of adjustment for multiple comparisons when running each model.

Committee Feedback

We predict that for our White participants, importance of racial similarity fit will interact with hierarchy-relevance of the role to predict applicant fit. Specifically, we predict that participants who highly endorse the belief that racial fit is important in hiring will prefer the White applicant in the hierarchy-enhancing versus hierarchy-attenuating role.

sample.value: The target sample size will be 600 participants (150 per cell: high versus low-status role; hierarchy-attenuating versus enhancing organization), enough to guarantee greater than 99% power to detect an interactive effect size of R = .21 (the average effect size in social psychology historically; Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003) after exclusions.

analyses.value: We will use two-way ANOVA models to test the main and interactive effects of applicant preferences in the high or low-status job in the hierarchy-attenuating or hierarchy-enhancing organization.

outliers.value: We will recruit participants who have indicated that they are White, excluding participants who do not indicate that they are White in a final demographic portion of the survey. These exclusions will be made prior to data analysis.

dependent.value:
In a scenario adapted from Pedulla (2014), participants will be asked to imagine consulting for a friend, who works at a local firm currently seeking a new CEO [entry level associate], by “reviewing the resume of one of the job candidates.” Participants will then be asked to thoroughly review the job applicant’s resume (approximately 60 seconds). Hierarchy-relevance of the high-status job will be manipulated by describing the role as “CEO [entry level associate] of a nonprofit” (hierarchy-attenuating) or “CEO [entry level associate] of a hedge fund” (hierarchy-enhancing). Each participant will then review the resume of a White job applicant. The key dependent variable is applicant preferences.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions—A high or low-status job at a  hierarchy-attenuating job or hierarchy-enhancing organization. Participants will be selected for the study if they are White, according to Prolific’s pre-screen questionnaire.

hypothesis.value: How does hierarchy-relevance of jobs impact Whites’ responses to Black and White job applicants? Prior work suggests that White evaluators rate White job applicants as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing job than a similarly high-status hierarchy-attenuating job. This study aims to replicate this effect and extend it by exploring the impact of job status. We predict a main effect of hierarchy-relevance of job (hierarchy-enhancing, hierarchy-attenuating) in predicting White evaluators’ ratings of White applicant fit, such that evaluators rate a White applicant as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing (versus -attenuating) job. As an exploratory step, we will also test whether this effect is moderated by job status (high, low) by asking evaluate an applicant seeking either a high-status (i.e., CEO) or low status (i.e., entry level associate) job at a hierarchy-enhancing (hedge fund) or hierarchy-enhancing (nonprofit) organization.

attributes.title: Can the Correct Interpretation of Probability be decided in a Minimal Formulation of Quantum Mechancis?
attributes.description: A term paper to be submitted to the Munich Center for Philosophy of Science as part of the Central Topics in Philosophy of Science core module

q1.value: Can the Correct Interpretation of Probability be decided in a Minimal Formulation of Quantum Mechanics?

q3.value: Because probability plays a key role in all branches of science, the study of its foundations and implications is of great significance to the philosophy of science. One such topic under study is the debate between the so-called subjectivist and objectivist interpretations of probability. My goal for this project is to identify the philosophical outcome of reconstructing this debate in the arena of quantum mechanics, a theory in which probabilities play the role of fundamental entities and their treatment extends beyond the limitations of the classical probability calculus.

q4.value:
If the subjectivist vs. objectivist debate is reconstructed within a minimal formulation of quantum mechanics sufficient to define observables and measurement outcomes, then the debate will be undecidable unless additional formal structure is incorporated into the quantum theory.

If additional formal structure is to be incorporated into the quantum theory, then this structure will be in the form of extensions of the classical probability calculus to account for the dynamical evolution of the wavefunction.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: One third of the paper will be allocated to reconstructing the debate on the subjectivist vs. objectivist interpretations of probability and stating the hypotheses. Once the hypotheses have been stated and justified, the selected sources will be read with the intent of extracting relevant arguments for and against both sides of the debate. These arguments will be presented in abridged form in the second third of the paper. The final third of the paper will constitute a synthesis between the evidence provided for the examined arguments and the justifications given for the hypotheses. The paper will end with an evaluation of whether the hypotheses agreed in consequence of the research or stand in need of revision.

q9.value: The sources to be examined in the second part of the paper will be stripped of title and author information and will be randomized in terms of reading order.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The existing data is contained in the arguments provided by the authors of the sources to be examined. By removing information about the title and author of each paper during review, I hope to remove bias about the authors’ affiliations and level of expertise.

question.value: The two main sources of the papers to be examined are the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy and the Probabilities in Physics book edited by Beisbart and Hartmann. The examined arguments will be excluded from the paper in terms of their relevance to the stated hypotheses, density of mathematical notation, and possibility of abridgement.

q13.value: The sample size will be constrained to the 9 sources in the bibliography. These are the sources that will be examined in depth to a) define the philosophical debate, b) determine the degree of support for the hypotheses.

q14.value: Sample size was chosen in terms of the number of arguments that can be considered within a 3000 word limit.

q15.value: Examination of the sources will stop the moment positive and negative arguments have been found for both sides of the debate as well the relation to the justifications provided for the initial hypotheses. At most, first-level citations from the examined sources will be incorporated to the discussion.

question.value: Two variables will be qualitatively measured per source examined: the degree of support for a subjectivist/objectivist interpretation of probability and the level of structure extending beyond the minimal formalization of quantum mechanics.
No statistical methods are involved in this study.
The data will be assessed dialectically, so no statistical models are applicable for the analysis.

q21.value: Deductive inference will be applied to assess the degree of support for a position and to determine the extension past the minimally specified framework at the onset.

q22.value: Data points will be excluded in terms of irrelevance to the research question.

q23.value: Incompleteness of data will be accounted for in terms of indicating the scope and limitations of the inferences drawn.

q25.value:
The end-product should not exceed 3000 (at most 4000) words in length. Hence, the following procedural outline is proposed:

Part I.
a. State the philosophical motivation to interpret probability
b. Distinguish the main positions in the debate
c. Propose exporting the debate to quantum mechanics
d. Indicate hypotheses

Part II.
a. Indicate the desiderata for a minimal formalization of quantum mechanics
b. Enumerate the axioms fulfilling these criteria

Part III.
a. Identify positive and negative arguments for objectivist interpretations
b. Assess the extension of these arguments past the minimal formulation
c. Identify positive and negative arguments for subjectivist interpretations
d. Assess the extension of these arguments past the minimal formulation

Part IV

a. Restate hypotheses
b. Evaluate whether hypotheses stand in need for revision
c. Summarize

q15.value: Candidates for political office in the United States often create both English and Spanish language versions of the same campaign advertisement. In terms of policy positions, candidate biographies, and political ideology, both versions convey the same information. By randomizing which version subjects view, we will measure the persuasive impact of the choice of language over and above the possible persuasive effects that may be caused by the content of the advertisements.

q16.value: Holding policy positions constant, we hypothesize that bilingual (Spanish- and English-speaking) voters will prefer candidates who address them in Spanish rather than English.

q3.value:
Führt eine Erhöhung der verfügbaren Informationsmenge (operationalisiert über Präsentationszeiten) zu einer Verstärkung vom perzeptuellen Similarity-Kontexteffekt?
Führt eine zeitliche Ausdehnung des Entscheidungsprozesses zu einer Verstärkung vom Similarity-Kontexteffekt?

q4.value:
1. Die Möglichkeit zur längeren Informationsaufnahme (operationalisiert durch längere Präsentationszeiten) führt zu einem stärkeren Similarity-Effekt als bei einer kürzeren (kürzere Präsentationszeit). (gerichtet)
2. Die Möglichkeit zur unbegrenzten Elaboration der Entscheidung führt zu einem stärkeren Similarity-Effekt als eine begrenzte. (operationalisiert durch eine Bedingung, in der die VP Zeitdruck haben und einer Bedingung, in der dies nicht der Fall ist). (gerichtet)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
o	Versuchsplan: Zweifaktorielles Within-Subjects-Design mit 4x2 Stufen
o	Randomisierungen: Randomisiert wurde innerhalb jeder Versuchsperson 
	a) der Höhenversatz der Rechtecke, 
	b) Seitenlängen (Höhe und Breite) der Rechtecke, 
	c) die Position der Focal Option und 
	d) die vier verschiedenen Präsentationszeiten
	e) Zwischen den Versuchsteilnehmer/innen wird die Reihenfolge der Blöcke randomisiert, d.h. ob sie mit der „speed“- oder der „accuracy“-Bedingung starten. Hier wurde zusätzlich die Rahmenfarbe der Bedingungen randomisiert zugeteilt.
o	Unabhängige Variablen (UVs):
	UV 1: Präsentationszeit; ordinalskaliert auf vier Stufen
•	Ausprägungen: 100, 400, 700 vs. 1000ms
	UV 2: Zeitlimit; dichotom (ja / nein)
•	A) Instruktion, so schnell und intuitiv wie möglich zu wählen vs. 
•	B) Instruktion, so präzise und genau wie möglich zu wählen
o	Abhängige Variablen (AVs): Anteil der Trials, in denen die fokale Option gewählt wurde (= relative Häufigkeit); kontinuierlich (binomialverteilt)

question.value:
Stichprobe:
Bei der Stichprobe, die an der Studie teilnimmt, wird es sich zum größten Teil um Studierende handeln, die an der Georg-August-Universität eingeschrieben sind. Als Aufwandentschädigung für die Teilnahme werden ihnen Getränke und Weihnachtsgebäck angeboten. Über Flyer und (Online- als auch Offline-)Ausschreibungen wird Werbung betrieben, um die benötigte Anzahl an Versuchsteilnehmer/innen zu rekutrieren. Die Datenerhebung wird voraussichtlich in der Kalenderwoche 50 und 51 des Jahres 2019 stattfinden.
Datenausschluss:
Wenn ein/e Versuchsteilnehmer/-in vor Ende des Experiments abbricht und nicht mindestens 50% aller Trials bearbeitet hat oder wenn ein/e Versuchsteilnehmer/-in in den Filler-Trials zwei Standardabweichungen von dem Mittelwert abweicht, werden diese Daten aus der Analyse ausgeschlossen.

q13.value:
Stichprobengröße:
Es wird eine Stichprobengröße von 25 Personen benötigt.

Begründung der Stichprobengröße: 
Via GPower ergab sich bei Annahme einer Durchführung einer Zweifaktoriellen Varianzanalyse (mit Messwiederholung auf beiden Faktoren) für die UV1 (=Präsentationszeit) eine benötigte Stichprobe von N=14, wenn wir von einer angepassenten Effektstärke von f‘=0.4, einer Teststärke von 0.8 und einer approximierten Korrelation zw. wdholten Messungen von 0.3 (eher klein, da 4 verschiedene Bedingungen) ausgehen. Für die UV2 (=Zeitdruck; 2-stufig) ergibt sich eine angepasste Effektstärke f‘=0.28 unter der Annahme einerselben Teststärke von 0.8 und einer approximierten Korrelation zw. wdholten Messungen von 0.55 (hier größer, da nur 2 verschiedene Bedingungen) kommt es zu einer Stichprobe von N = 25. So wird sich auf eine Stichprobengröße von 25 geeigent. GPower kann keine exakte Planung für zweifaktorielle Messwiederholdesigns ausführen, deswegen wird die Stichprobenplanung für beide Faktoren separat ausgeführt.

Statistisches Model:
Um eine ANOVA zu berechnen, muss eine Wurzel-Arcussinus-Transformation der einzelnen Werte durchgeführt werden. Eine ANOVA ist erforderlich, da wir ein mehrfaktorielles Design zugrunde liegen haben. Die ANOVA berechnet den Einfluss der einzelnen Prädiktoren auf die Wahl der fokalen Option (=Operationalisierung des Similarity-Effekts). Prädiktoren stellen die Präsentationszeiten und die Zeitdruckvariable dar, für die ein Effekt auf die Wahl der fokalen Option vermutet wird. Eventuell wird noch ein t-Test durchgeführt, um die Richtung des Effekts zu testen.

q20.value: Wie oben genannt wird eine Wurzel-ArcusSinus-Transformation für die relative Häufigkeit der Wahl der fokalen Option eines jeden einzelnen Versuchsteilnehmer durchgeführt. Die Transformation dient zur Erfüllung der Bedingung, dass normalverteilte Variablen vorliegen.

q21.value: Wenn die Varianzen, die durch die beiden Prädiktoren an der Gesamtvarianz des Kriteriums aufgeklärt werden, signifikant werden (d.h. p<=0.05), wird von einem Effekt der Prädiktoren ausgegangen.

q22.value: Wenn ein/e Versuchsteilnehmer/-in vor Ende des Experiments abbricht und nicht mindestens 50% aller Trials bearbeitet hat oder wenn ein/e Versuchsteilnehmer/-in in den Filler-Trials zwei Standardabweichungen von dem Mittelwert abweicht, werden diese Daten aus der Analyse ausgeschlossen.

q23.value: Fehlende Daten werden aus der Analyse herausgenommen.

q24.value: Eine mögliche Interaktion zwischen UV1 und UV2 soll eventuell noch überprüft werden.

registration_responses.q4:
1. Die Möglichkeit zur längeren Informationsaufnahme (operationalisiert durch längere Präsentationszeiten) führt zu einem stärkeren Similarity-Effekt als bei einer kürzeren (kürzere Präsentationszeit). (gerichtet)
2. Die Möglichkeit zur unbegrenzten Elaboration der Entscheidung führt zu einem stärkeren Similarity-Effekt als eine begrenzte. (operationalisiert durch eine Bedingung, in der die VP Zeitdruck haben und einer Bedingung, in der dies nicht der Fall ist). (gerichtet)
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
