registration_responses.q13:
Stichprobengröße:
Es wird eine Stichprobengröße von 25 Personen benötigt.

Begründung der Stichprobengröße: 
Via GPower ergab sich bei Annahme einer Durchführung einer Zweifaktoriellen Varianzanalyse (mit Messwiederholung auf beiden Faktoren) für die UV1 (=Präsentationszeit) eine benötigte Stichprobe von N=14, wenn wir von einer angepassenten Effektstärke von f‘=0.4, einer Teststärke von 0.8 und einer approximierten Korrelation zw. wdholten Messungen von 0.3 (eher klein, da 4 verschiedene Bedingungen) ausgehen. Für die UV2 (=Zeitdruck; 2-stufig) ergibt sich eine angepasste Effektstärke f‘=0.28 unter der Annahme einerselben Teststärke von 0.8 und einer approximierten Korrelation zw. wdholten Messungen von 0.55 (hier größer, da nur 2 verschiedene Bedingungen) kommt es zu einer Stichprobe von N = 25. So wird sich auf eine Stichprobengröße von 25 geeigent. GPower kann keine exakte Planung für zweifaktorielle Messwiederholdesigns ausführen, deswegen wird die Stichprobenplanung für beide Faktoren separat ausgeführt.

registration_responses.q8.question:
o	Versuchsplan: Zweifaktorielles Within-Subjects-Design mit 4x2 Stufen
o	Randomisierungen: Randomisiert wurde innerhalb jeder Versuchsperson 
	a) der Höhenversatz der Rechtecke, 
	b) Seitenlängen (Höhe und Breite) der Rechtecke, 
	c) die Position der Focal Option und 
	d) die vier verschiedenen Präsentationszeiten
	e) Zwischen den Versuchsteilnehmer/innen wird die Reihenfolge der Blöcke randomisiert, d.h. ob sie mit der „speed“- oder der „accuracy“-Bedingung starten. Hier wurde zusätzlich die Rahmenfarbe der Bedingungen randomisiert zugeteilt.
o	Unabhängige Variablen (UVs):
	UV 1: Präsentationszeit; ordinalskaliert auf vier Stufen
•	Ausprägungen: 100, 400, 700 vs. 1000ms
	UV 2: Zeitlimit; dichotom (ja / nein)
•	A) Instruktion, so schnell und intuitiv wie möglich zu wählen vs. 
•	B) Instruktion, so präzise und genau wie möglich zu wählen
o	Abhängige Variablen (AVs): Anteil der Trials, in denen die fokale Option gewählt wurde (= relative Häufigkeit); kontinuierlich (binomialverteilt)
registration_responses.q12.question:
Stichprobe:
Bei der Stichprobe, die an der Studie teilnimmt, wird es sich zum größten Teil um Studierende handeln, die an der Georg-August-Universität eingeschrieben sind. Als Aufwandentschädigung für die Teilnahme werden ihnen Getränke und Weihnachtsgebäck angeboten. Über Flyer und (Online- als auch Offline-)Ausschreibungen wird Werbung betrieben, um die benötigte Anzahl an Versuchsteilnehmer/innen zu rekutrieren. Die Datenerhebung wird voraussichtlich in der Kalenderwoche 50 und 51 des Jahres 2019 stattfinden.

Statistisches Model:
Um eine ANOVA zu berechnen, muss eine Wurzel-Arcussinus-Transformation der einzelnen Werte durchgeführt werden. Eine ANOVA ist erforderlich, da wir ein mehrfaktorielles Design zugrunde liegen haben. Die ANOVA berechnet den Einfluss der einzelnen Prädiktoren auf die Wahl der fokalen Option (=Operationalisierung des Similarity-Effekts). Prädiktoren stellen die Präsentationszeiten und die Zeitdruckvariable dar, für die ein Effekt auf die Wahl der fokalen Option vermutet wird. Eventuell wird noch ein t-Test durchgeführt, um die Richtung des Effekts zu testen.

q1.value: The relation between decision weighting and subclinical anxiety in decisions from description

q2.value: Samuel Zorowitz, Daniel Bennett, Yael Niv

q3.value: Exaggerated threat appraisal is a core feature of anxiety. Historically, clinical theories have posited that this symptom results from distortions in patients’ subjective probability estimates of future threat (Clark & Beck, 2011; Guilford Press).In contrast, recent computational psychiatry research (Charpentier et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2016.12.010) has suggested this symptom is better described by stronger economic risk aversion, i.e. as a steeper discounting of marginal subjective value. This previous study is unable, by virtue of its design, to assess whether biased risk preferences in anxiety are a function of risk aversion, decision weighting (i.e., distorted subjective probability estimates), or both. Here we investigate whether pessimistic appraisals in anxiety are better characterized by differences in the representation of reward value and/or probability.

q4.value:
H1: Subclinical anxiety will be positively correlated with a preference for certain over risky gambles in decisions from description. 

H2: Subclinical anxiety will be positively correlated with pessimism in the interpretation of probabilities, as measured by decreased probability elevation in gains (delta-plus parameter of prospect theory models) and increased probability elevation in losses (delta-minus parameter of prospect theory models).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The experiment is a repeated measures design, meaning that all participants will complete the same set of gambles and questionnaires.

q9.value: Within the experiment, the order of the gambles will be randomized across participants. Similarly, the order of the questionnaires (STAI-T, GAD-7, IPIP-NEO Extraversion scale), and the items comprising each, will be randomized across participants. The order of blocks (gambles vs. questionnaires) will be counterbalanced across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Pilot data were collected for this study to ensure that (1) participants understood instructions, (2) gambles were well calibrated (no ceiling/floor effects), and (3) payments were proportional to time taken on task. 

Though the data were inspected for quality assurance purposes (e.g. to quantify proportion of inattentive participants), no primary analysis of the pilot data was performed. In other words, we computed no correlations between choice behavior and questionnaire self-report data prior to collection of the experimental data.

question.value:
All subjects will be recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). Data collection will continue until 450 usable datasets have been collected. Participants who complete the task but who are excluded due to the exclusion criteria defined below will be replaced until 450 usable datasets have been collected. 

Data collection from Amazon Mechanical Turk is faster than traditional behavioral data collection methods and is expected to be completed within one month. Participants will be paid a base payment of $4.00 and a performance bonus for their participation in the 20 minute study. A participant's bonus is calculated by playing out each gamble they chose and paying out a proportion of the total earnings. Bonuses will be in the range of $0.00-$2.00. (Participants can never lose money.) Participants who drop out of the experiment will not receive this payment, and their data will be excluded. Participants who complete the task but are excluded due to the exclusion criteria defined below will be paid.

Recruited participants will be from the US to ensure understanding of the task (i.e. gambles in American dollars). Following recent recommendations (Robinson et al., 2019, DOI: 10.31234/osf.io/jq589), the study will be available to all AMT workers, irrespective of approval rate, to increase the likelihood of recruiting naive participants.

q13.value: 450 human participants will be recruited. The experiment is an individual-differences study. All participants will see the same set of gambles and will fill out the same battery of questionnaires.

q14.value:
450 participants will be included in the analysis. This will allow us to detect an effect size of r = 0.15 at 80% power. 

The sample size was determined prior to data collection using Bayesian power analysis (Kruschke, 2015, Academic Press). Briefly, we determined through computational simulation the minimal sample size necessary to reliably (80% power) detect a correlation between gambling behavior and self-reported anxiety at r = 0.15. The data generating parameters for the simulations were dictated by empirical priors estimated from behavior in five publicly available datasets (N=323 total participants) of decisions from description. The full details and results of the power analysis are available here (https://github.com/nivlab/AnxiousProspects/releases/tag/preregistration). 

A sample size of 450 participants is similar to the a priori defined samples sizes of several other recent computational psychiatry studies of individual differences (Norbury et al., 2018, DOI: 10.7554/eLife.34779; Rouault et al., 2018, DOI: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2017.12.017; Seow \& Gillan, 2019, DOI: 10.1101/664003).

q15.value: Once 450 usable datasets have been collected recruitment will stop, with excluded participants replaced as necessary. Exclusions will take place prior to analysis of any hypotheses (i.e., the only analyses that will take place prior to exclusions are those strictly necessary to identify participants for exclusion).

question.value:
The primary assay in this experiment is the gambles presented to participants. There are 104 total gambles, which are balanced in valence (gains vs. losses) and problem type (certain vs. risky, risky vs. risky). The gambles were designed to emulate properties of gambles from previous studies. They encompass a diverse range of outcome probabilities and magnitudes. Outcome probabilities and magnitudes were decorrelated in order to decouple their potential influence on choice behavior.

All participants will observe the same set of gambles. The list of gambles is presented in the attached CSV file.

We will collect three self-report measures: 

1. The trait subscale of the Spielberger State Trait Anxiety inventory (STAI-T; Spielberger, 1983, DOI: http://hdl.handle.net/10477/1873). The STAI-T is as our measure of subclinical anxiety.

2. The 7-item Generalized Anxiety Disorder scale (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006, DOI: 10.1001/archinte.166.10.1092). The GAD-7 serves as a measure of convergent validity. Previous research has suggested the STAI-T is more so a measure of negative affect than trait anxiety (Bados et al., 2010; DOI: 10.1080/00223891.2010.513295). We will use the GAD-7 as an additional measure of trait anxiety, as it shows good construct validity (Beard & Björgvinsson, 2014; DOI: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2014.06.002) and discriminative validity (Rutter & Brown, 2017; DOI: 10.1007/s10862-016-9571-9). 

3. The extraversion subscale of the 50-item IPIP NEO-PI-R inventory. The IPIP NEO-PI-R is as our positive control, as extraversion has previously been found to correlate with risk-seeking in decisions from description (Frey et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.1701381).

In addition, the following demographic information will also be collected: age, gender, ethnicity, race, and English proficiency.

The primary measured variable for H1 is the proportion of risky over certain gamble choices. In total, there are 52 gambles (26 gain, 26 loss) of this type. We will measure the overall proportion of risky over certain gambles (averaging within participants across gain and loss), as well as the valence-specific proportions (gain-only, loss-only).

The primary measured variables for H2 are the cumulative prospect theory (CPT) model parameters. We are particularly interested in the probability elevation parameters (delta-plus and delta-minus). These will be estimated for each participant from their respective choice data (see Statistical Models).

The items of each self-report measure (STAI-T, GAD-7 IPIP NEO-PI-R Extraversion) will be summed into three sum scores per participant. Items will be reverse-scored where appropriate. All sum scores will be normalized to proportions in the range [0,1], according to each measures' respective maximum possible score. Proportion scores will be endpoint-corrected following the recommendations of Smithson & Verkuilen (2006, DOI: 10.1037/1082-989X.11.1.54).  

As noted above, we will measure the proportion of risky over certain gamble choices. In total, there are 52 gambles (26 gain, 26 loss) of this type. We will measure the overall proportion of risky over certain gambles (averaging within participants across gain and loss), as well as the domain-specific proportions (gain-only, loss-only).

H1: Subclinical anxiety will positively correlate with a preference for certain over risky gambles.

We will fit a Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regressing proportional trait anxiety scores (i.e. STAI-T sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the proportion of choices for certain over risky gambles (i.e. average of choice across the 52 certain/risky gambles). The regression model involves three free parameters: an intercept term (capturing average anxiety scores), a slope term (capturing the correlation between choice preference and anxiety), and dispersion (variance) parameter. This analysis will be repeated for the gain- and loss-only trials (26 each, respectively) to test if the effects of anxiety on risk preferences are restricted to a particular outcome domain.

To measure convergent validity, we will repeat the analyses above using instead the proportional generalized anxiety scores (i.e. GAD-7 sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. We will determine evidence for H1 with respect to the correlation between the two anxiety measures. Specifically, if scores on the STAI and GAD-7 are strongly correlated and, in turn, both are correlated with risk preferences, then we would interpret the results as in partial support H1 noting that future research will be needed to better disentangle the influence anxiety and negative affect on risk preferences. On the other hand, if they are uncorrelated, we will interpret the results with respect to the independent correlations of each measure with risk preferences.

As a positive control, we will fit a separate Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regressing proportional extraversion scores (i.e. IPIP NEO-PI-R sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the proportion of choices for certain over risky gambles (i.e. average of choice across the 52 certain/risky gambles). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. 

H2: Subclinical anxiety will be positively correlated with pessimism in the interpretation of probabilities, as measured by decreased probability elevation in gains (delta-plus parameter of prospect theory models) and increased probability elevation in losses (delta-minus parameter of prospect theory models).

We will fit a Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regression proportional anxiety scores (i.e. STAI-T sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the estimated probability elevation parameters from our CPT model. The regression model involves three free parameters as above. 

To measure individual differences in probability weighting, we will fit hierarchical Bayesian cumulative prospect theory (CPT) models to the choice data. Despite the long history of CPT, there is no single agreed-upon CPT model; the best-fitting variant of CPT models varies across studies & datasets.

As such, we plan to test three variants of CPT models. The most basic (CPT-A) consists of five parameters: risk sensitivity (alpha), probability curvature (gamma), probability elevation in gain (delta-plus), probability elevation in loss (delta-minus), and choice sensitivity (theta). Note that this model allows for different evaluations of probabilities in gains vs. losses, and eliminates the common loss aversion parameter. This design choice is motivated by recent evidence which found probability elevation to be domain dependent and to better explain putative loss aversion (Pachur & Kellen, 2013, https://escholarship.org/uc/item/27n5s4wn).

The second and third families of models (CPT-B, CPT-C) are both extensions of CPT-A. The CPT-B models differ in that they include loss aversion (lambda), whereas the CPT-C models differ in that they include separate probability curvature parameters for gain and loss (gamma-plus, gamma-minus). CPT-B is motivated by the canonical CPT literature on loss aversion; CPT-C is motivated by previous work which found domain dependencies on probability curvature (Pachur & Kellen, 2013, https://escholarship.org/uc/item/27n5s4wn).

All models will be fit using the Stan probabilistic programming language. Both no-pooling and partial-pooling versions of each model will be fit, where the former fits each participant separately and the latter estimates participant parameters constrained by a group-level distribution. To determine the best-fitting of the six models, the Widely Applicable Information Criterion (WAIC) will be computed for each model at the level of the participant. The best fitting model should have a greater WAIC with non-overlapping standard errors of the difference in WAIC between it and other models (the delta-WAIC statistic). If there is a tie, we will appeal to parsimony (i.e., select the model with fewer parameters).

We note that we will be running the best-fitting CPT model and beta regression simultaneously (i.e. joint-modeling). The Bayesian joint-modeling framework naturally takes into account uncertainty in parameter estimates, thereby downweighting the influence of noisy or uncertain parameters in the correlation (Boehm et al., 2018, DOI: 10.3758/s13428-017-0940-4).

We have already programmed the analysis models in Stan, and are available for inspection here (https://github.com/nivlab/AnxiousProspects/releases/tag/preregistration). Following previous convention (Scheibehenne &  Pachur, 2015, DOI 10.3758/s13423-014-0684-4; Pachur et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1016/j.cogpsych.2017.01.001), the risk sensitivity (alpha) and probability curvature (gamma) parameters are sampled in the range of [0,2], the loss aversion (lambda) and probability elevation (delta-plus, delta-minus) are log-normal distributed. In turn, the choice sensitivity parameter (theta) is sampled in the range of [0,1], which we found to be appropriate for the magnitude range of our gambles. 

To measure convergent validity, we will repeat the same analyses above using instead the proportional generalized anxiety scores (i.e. GAD-7 sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. We will determine evidence for H2 with respect to the correlation between the two anxiety measures. Specifically, if scores on the STAI and GAD-7 are strongly correlated and, in turn, both are correlated with probability weighting, then we would interpret the results as in partial support H2 noting that future research will be needed to better disentangle the influence anxiety and negative affect on probability weighting. On the other hand, if they are uncorrelated, we will interpret the results with respect to the independent correlations of each measure with probability weighting.

q20.value:
The items of each self-report measure (STAI-T, GAD-7, IPIP NEO-PI-R Extraversion) will be summed into three sum scores per participant. Items will be reverse-scored where appropriate. All sum scores will be normalized to proportions in the range [0,1], according to each measures' respective maximum possible score. Proportion scores will be endpoint-corrected following the recommendations of Smithson & Verkuilen (2006, DOI: 10.1037/1082-989X.11.1.54).

The independent variables of the beta regression (H1: proportion of certain choices; H2: probability elevation parameters) will be z-scored (i.e. transformed into unit-scale) prior to regression.

q21.value: Bayesian highest density intervals (HDIs) will be computed for the slope coefficient parameters of the beta regression models. If the 95% HDI excludes zero, we will treat that as evidence of a correlation. To combat against the possibility of false positives due to multiple comparisons, we have assigned conservative priors to the slope coefficient (i.e. the proxy for the correlation). Specifically, we follow the guidelines recommended by Gignac & Szodorai (2016; DOI: 10.1016/j.paid.2016.06.069) who find that the average effect size of a behavior-questionnaire correlation is r=0.2. As such, we assign a N(0,0.2) prior to the slope coefficient, to shrink estimates towards zero. In practice, such conservative priors in Bayesian analysis have the effect of mitigating false positives (Gelman et al., 2012, DOI: 10.1080/19345747.2011.618213).

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded under the following criteria:

1. Failure to complete the entire task (104 gambles), attention checks (6 gambles), and questionnaires.
2. Incorrect response on two or more gamble attention checks (see attached CSV).
3. 90% of choices characterized by one or more of the following heuristics: side (always choosing left or right gamble), maximax (choose the gamble with the highest outcome), minimax (choose the gamble with the highest minimum outcome), least-likely (identify each gamble’s worst outcome, then choose the gamble with the lowest probability of the worst outcome), most-likely (identify each gamble’s most likely outcome, then choose the gamble with the highest, most likely outcome) (Pachur et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1016/j.cogpsych.2017.01.001).
4. Response times of less than 2s on 50% or more of the gambles. 
5. Average response time on questionnaire items of less than 1s per item.

Exclusions will be conducted prior to data analysis.

q23.value: Participants who have not completed the task and questionnaires will be excluded from the analysis. The experiment is programmed so no items can be skipped. If any item is missing from the dataset due to computer error, then the corresponding participant will be excluded.

q24.value: As an exploratory analysis, we will fit the beta regression model between the STAI-T and GAD-7 and all remaining CPT parameters. We do not have any a priori predictions about any relationships we may between these sets of variables.

450 participants will be included in the analysis. This will allow us to detect an effect size of r = 0.15 at 80% power. 

The sample size was determined prior to data collection using Bayesian power analysis (Kruschke, 2015, Academic Press). Briefly, we determined through computational simulation the minimal sample size necessary to reliably (80% power) detect a correlation between gambling behavior and self-reported anxiety at r = 0.15. The data generating parameters for the simulations were dictated by empirical priors estimated from behavior in five publicly available datasets (N=323 total participants) of decisions from description. The full details and results of the power analysis are available here (https://github.com/nivlab/AnxiousProspects/releases/tag/preregistration). 

A sample size of 450 participants is similar to the a priori defined samples sizes of several other recent computational psychiatry studies of individual differences (Norbury et al., 2018, DOI: 10.7554/eLife.34779; Rouault et al., 2018, DOI: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2017.12.017; Seow \& Gillan, 2019, DOI: 10.1101/664003).
registration_responses.q15: Once 450 usable datasets have been collected recruitment will stop, with excluded participants replaced as necessary. Exclusions will take place prior to analysis of any hypotheses (i.e., the only analyses that will take place prior to exclusions are those strictly necessary to identify participants for exclusion).
registration_responses.q20:
The items of each self-report measure (STAI-T, GAD-7, IPIP NEO-PI-R Extraversion) will be summed into three sum scores per participant. Items will be reverse-scored where appropriate. All sum scores will be normalized to proportions in the range [0,1], according to each measures' respective maximum possible score. Proportion scores will be endpoint-corrected following the recommendations of Smithson & Verkuilen (2006, DOI: 10.1037/1082-989X.11.1.54).

The independent variables of the beta regression (H1: proportion of certain choices; H2: probability elevation parameters) will be z-scored (i.e. transformed into unit-scale) prior to regression.
registration_responses.q21: Bayesian highest density intervals (HDIs) will be computed for the slope coefficient parameters of the beta regression models. If the 95% HDI excludes zero, we will treat that as evidence of a correlation. To combat against the possibility of false positives due to multiple comparisons, we have assigned conservative priors to the slope coefficient (i.e. the proxy for the correlation). Specifically, we follow the guidelines recommended by Gignac & Szodorai (2016; DOI: 10.1016/j.paid.2016.06.069) who find that the average effect size of a behavior-questionnaire correlation is r=0.2. As such, we assign a N(0,0.2) prior to the slope coefficient, to shrink estimates towards zero. In practice, such conservative priors in Bayesian analysis have the effect of mitigating false positives (Gelman et al., 2012, DOI: 10.1080/19345747.2011.618213).
registration_responses.q22:
Participants will be excluded under the following criteria:

1. Failure to complete the entire task (104 gambles), attention checks (6 gambles), and questionnaires.
2. Incorrect response on two or more gamble attention checks (see attached CSV).
3. 90% of choices characterized by one or more of the following heuristics: side (always choosing left or right gamble), maximax (choose the gamble with the highest outcome), minimax (choose the gamble with the highest minimum outcome), least-likely (identify each gamble’s worst outcome, then choose the gamble with the lowest probability of the worst outcome), most-likely (identify each gamble’s most likely outcome, then choose the gamble with the highest, most likely outcome) (Pachur et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1016/j.cogpsych.2017.01.001).
4. Response times of less than 2s on 50% or more of the gambles. 
5. Average response time on questionnaire items of less than 1s per item.

Exclusions will be conducted prior to data analysis.
registration_responses.q23: Participants who have not completed the task and questionnaires will be excluded from the analysis. The experiment is programmed so no items can be skipped. If any item is missing from the dataset due to computer error, then the corresponding participant will be excluded.
registration_responses.q24: As an exploratory analysis, we will fit the beta regression model between the STAI-T and GAD-7 and all remaining CPT parameters. We do not have any a priori predictions about any relationships we may between these sets of variables.
registration_responses.q8.question: The experiment is a repeated measures design, meaning that all participants will complete the same set of gambles and questionnaires.
registration_responses.q12.question:
All subjects will be recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). Data collection will continue until 450 usable datasets have been collected. Participants who complete the task but who are excluded due to the exclusion criteria defined below will be replaced until 450 usable datasets have been collected. 

Data collection from Amazon Mechanical Turk is faster than traditional behavioral data collection methods and is expected to be completed within one month. Participants will be paid a base payment of $4.00 and a performance bonus for their participation in the 20 minute study. A participant's bonus is calculated by playing out each gamble they chose and paying out a proportion of the total earnings. Bonuses will be in the range of $0.00-$2.00. (Participants can never lose money.) Participants who drop out of the experiment will not receive this payment, and their data will be excluded. Participants who complete the task but are excluded due to the exclusion criteria defined below will be paid.

Recruited participants will be from the US to ensure understanding of the task (i.e. gambles in American dollars). Following recent recommendations (Robinson et al., 2019, DOI: 10.31234/osf.io/jq589), the study will be available to all AMT workers, irrespective of approval rate, to increase the likelihood of recruiting naive participants.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The primary assay in this experiment is the gambles presented to participants. There are 104 total gambles, which are balanced in valence (gains vs. losses) and problem type (certain vs. risky, risky vs. risky). The gambles were designed to emulate properties of gambles from previous studies. They encompass a diverse range of outcome probabilities and magnitudes. Outcome probabilities and magnitudes were decorrelated in order to decouple their potential influence on choice behavior.

All participants will observe the same set of gambles. The list of gambles is presented in the attached CSV file.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will collect three self-report measures: 

1. The trait subscale of the Spielberger State Trait Anxiety inventory (STAI-T; Spielberger, 1983, DOI: http://hdl.handle.net/10477/1873). The STAI-T is as our measure of subclinical anxiety.

2. The 7-item Generalized Anxiety Disorder scale (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006, DOI: 10.1001/archinte.166.10.1092). The GAD-7 serves as a measure of convergent validity. Previous research has suggested the STAI-T is more so a measure of negative affect than trait anxiety (Bados et al., 2010; DOI: 10.1080/00223891.2010.513295). We will use the GAD-7 as an additional measure of trait anxiety, as it shows good construct validity (Beard & Björgvinsson, 2014; DOI: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2014.06.002) and discriminative validity (Rutter & Brown, 2017; DOI: 10.1007/s10862-016-9571-9). 

3. The extraversion subscale of the 50-item IPIP NEO-PI-R inventory. The IPIP NEO-PI-R is as our positive control, as extraversion has previously been found to correlate with risk-seeking in decisions from description (Frey et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.1701381).

In addition, the following demographic information will also be collected: age, gender, ethnicity, race, and English proficiency.

The primary measured variable for H1 is the proportion of risky over certain gamble choices. In total, there are 52 gambles (26 gain, 26 loss) of this type. We will measure the overall proportion of risky over certain gambles (averaging within participants across gain and loss), as well as the valence-specific proportions (gain-only, loss-only).

The primary measured variables for H2 are the cumulative prospect theory (CPT) model parameters. We are particularly interested in the probability elevation parameters (delta-plus and delta-minus). These will be estimated for each participant from their respective choice data (see Statistical Models).
registration_responses.q18.question:
The items of each self-report measure (STAI-T, GAD-7 IPIP NEO-PI-R Extraversion) will be summed into three sum scores per participant. Items will be reverse-scored where appropriate. All sum scores will be normalized to proportions in the range [0,1], according to each measures' respective maximum possible score. Proportion scores will be endpoint-corrected following the recommendations of Smithson & Verkuilen (2006, DOI: 10.1037/1082-989X.11.1.54).  

As noted above, we will measure the proportion of risky over certain gamble choices. In total, there are 52 gambles (26 gain, 26 loss) of this type. We will measure the overall proportion of risky over certain gambles (averaging within participants across gain and loss), as well as the domain-specific proportions (gain-only, loss-only).
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: Subclinical anxiety will positively correlate with a preference for certain over risky gambles.

We will fit a Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regressing proportional trait anxiety scores (i.e. STAI-T sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the proportion of choices for certain over risky gambles (i.e. average of choice across the 52 certain/risky gambles). The regression model involves three free parameters: an intercept term (capturing average anxiety scores), a slope term (capturing the correlation between choice preference and anxiety), and dispersion (variance) parameter. This analysis will be repeated for the gain- and loss-only trials (26 each, respectively) to test if the effects of anxiety on risk preferences are restricted to a particular outcome domain.

To measure convergent validity, we will repeat the analyses above using instead the proportional generalized anxiety scores (i.e. GAD-7 sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. We will determine evidence for H1 with respect to the correlation between the two anxiety measures. Specifically, if scores on the STAI and GAD-7 are strongly correlated and, in turn, both are correlated with risk preferences, then we would interpret the results as in partial support H1 noting that future research will be needed to better disentangle the influence anxiety and negative affect on risk preferences. On the other hand, if they are uncorrelated, we will interpret the results with respect to the independent correlations of each measure with risk preferences.

As a positive control, we will fit a separate Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regressing proportional extraversion scores (i.e. IPIP NEO-PI-R sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the proportion of choices for certain over risky gambles (i.e. average of choice across the 52 certain/risky gambles). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. 

H2: Subclinical anxiety will be positively correlated with pessimism in the interpretation of probabilities, as measured by decreased probability elevation in gains (delta-plus parameter of prospect theory models) and increased probability elevation in losses (delta-minus parameter of prospect theory models).

We will fit a Bayesian beta regression model using Stan, regression proportional anxiety scores (i.e. STAI-T sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]) on the estimated probability elevation parameters from our CPT model. The regression model involves three free parameters as above. 

To measure individual differences in probability weighting, we will fit hierarchical Bayesian cumulative prospect theory (CPT) models to the choice data. Despite the long history of CPT, there is no single agreed-upon CPT model; the best-fitting variant of CPT models varies across studies & datasets.

As such, we plan to test three variants of CPT models. The most basic (CPT-A) consists of five parameters: risk sensitivity (alpha), probability curvature (gamma), probability elevation in gain (delta-plus), probability elevation in loss (delta-minus), and choice sensitivity (theta). Note that this model allows for different evaluations of probabilities in gains vs. losses, and eliminates the common loss aversion parameter. This design choice is motivated by recent evidence which found probability elevation to be domain dependent and to better explain putative loss aversion (Pachur & Kellen, 2013, https://escholarship.org/uc/item/27n5s4wn).

The second and third families of models (CPT-B, CPT-C) are both extensions of CPT-A. The CPT-B models differ in that they include loss aversion (lambda), whereas the CPT-C models differ in that they include separate probability curvature parameters for gain and loss (gamma-plus, gamma-minus). CPT-B is motivated by the canonical CPT literature on loss aversion; CPT-C is motivated by previous work which found domain dependencies on probability curvature (Pachur & Kellen, 2013, https://escholarship.org/uc/item/27n5s4wn).

All models will be fit using the Stan probabilistic programming language. Both no-pooling and partial-pooling versions of each model will be fit, where the former fits each participant separately and the latter estimates participant parameters constrained by a group-level distribution. To determine the best-fitting of the six models, the Widely Applicable Information Criterion (WAIC) will be computed for each model at the level of the participant. The best fitting model should have a greater WAIC with non-overlapping standard errors of the difference in WAIC between it and other models (the delta-WAIC statistic). If there is a tie, we will appeal to parsimony (i.e., select the model with fewer parameters).

We note that we will be running the best-fitting CPT model and beta regression simultaneously (i.e. joint-modeling). The Bayesian joint-modeling framework naturally takes into account uncertainty in parameter estimates, thereby downweighting the influence of noisy or uncertain parameters in the correlation (Boehm et al., 2018, DOI: 10.3758/s13428-017-0940-4).

We have already programmed the analysis models in Stan, and are available for inspection here (https://github.com/nivlab/AnxiousProspects/releases/tag/preregistration). Following previous convention (Scheibehenne &  Pachur, 2015, DOI 10.3758/s13423-014-0684-4; Pachur et al., 2017, DOI: 10.1016/j.cogpsych.2017.01.001), the risk sensitivity (alpha) and probability curvature (gamma) parameters are sampled in the range of [0,2], the loss aversion (lambda) and probability elevation (delta-plus, delta-minus) are log-normal distributed. In turn, the choice sensitivity parameter (theta) is sampled in the range of [0,1], which we found to be appropriate for the magnitude range of our gambles. 

To measure convergent validity, we will repeat the same analyses above using instead the proportional generalized anxiety scores (i.e. GAD-7 sum scores, normalized to the range of [0,1]). The regression model involves three free parameters as above. We will determine evidence for H2 with respect to the correlation between the two anxiety measures. Specifically, if scores on the STAI and GAD-7 are strongly correlated and, in turn, both are correlated with probability weighting, then we would interpret the results as in partial support H2 noting that future research will be needed to better disentangle the influence anxiety and negative affect on probability weighting. On the other hand, if they are uncorrelated, we will interpret the results with respect to the independent correlations of each measure with probability weighting.

attributes.title: Virtual Reality distraction for needle-related pain in children: a multi-center study.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Virtual Reality distraction for needle-related pain in children: a multi-centre study.

other.value:
An exploratory analysis will be conducted with multivariable linear regression model, using predictors of age, sex, self-rated distractedness, prior needle exposure, and group (vr/non-vr/control).

Following variables will be collected for exploratory purposes:
1.	Medical staff and parent satisfaction – assessed with a standardized questionnaire.  
2.	Numerical rating scale (NRS)
3.	Self-reported level of being distracted – assessed by the child with a single question
4.	Procedure Behavior Check List (PBCL) – parent or caregiver ratings of pain/anxiety related behaviors of a child.

sample.value:
A minimum clinically significant difference in primary outcome measure FPS-R is 2/10 change in raw score (Tsze et al. 2015). The standard deviation for FPS-R in children can be estimated at 3.34/10 (Hicks et al. 2001). This translates to effect size d=0.6, which can then be considered a minimal clinically significant effect size for FPS-R results in children.

In order to answer the question if VR distraction is any better than the non-VR method, we assume statistical power of 95%, and alpha 5%. Power calculations (computed using G*Power software) determine that required sample size is 74 participants per group.   

In order to compensate for possible missing data, we decided to recruit 80 participants per group (VR distraction, non-VR distraction, control), giving a total sample size of 240.

analyses.value: A One-way ANCOVA will be conducted to determine a statistically significant difference between VR distraction, non-VR distraction and no distraction on pain intensity, controlling for geographical locations (centers). Centers will be coded as dummy variables and included as covariates.

outliers.value:
Exclusion criteria – medical conditions that preclude virtual reality use, or mobile screen distraction use: epileptic seizures, vision problems, hand/fingers mobility issues (active control game is played with a hand/finger).
Conditions that prevent the ability to give answers on dependent variables measures, inability to obtain consent from a caregiver, and assent from a child.

dependent.value:
1.	Self-reported pain intensity – measured with the Faces Pain Scale-Revised (FPS-R)

2.	Child anxiety/stress level – assessed by a nurse or parent with a single question:
“Please rate the child's degree of observed distress during the blood draw” 0 – not distressed ; 10 – very distressed

conditions.value:
Each center will implement a between-group experimental study design. The independent variable is a distraction type on three levels. Each participant will be randomly allocated to one of three groups:
1.	VR distraction. 
2.	Active control - non-VR distraction.
3.	Passive control – treatment as usual. 

VR distraction intervention 
Participants randomized to the VR distraction intervention will be playing a game using the Samsung Gear VR system with Galaxy S8 phone. The game, created by the authors of this study (University of Wroclaw), consists of memorizing and finding several flashing elements that briefly appear among moving objects on a screen. Furthermore, the game consists of several scenes with different backgrounds and numbers of flying objects. This design makes the VR session more attractive for participants and enables its application for children of various ages.
The VR distraction intervention is based on the Multiple Object Tracking (MOT) paradigm. 

Non-VR distraction
Participants will be playing a 2d version of the MOT game on a mobile phone screen. 
 
Passive Control 
Children in the control group will undergo a blood draw without any specific means of distracting their attention away from the procedure. However, for ethical reasons, neither parents nor nurses will be instructed to refrain from conducting any behaviors that may distract a child from the procedure.

hypothesis.value:
Research questions / objectives:
To test if VR based distraction is more effective than a non-VR distraction in diminishing needle-related pain and anxiety in children undergoing venous blood draw.
To obtain an estimate of effect size for VR distraction compared to no distraction control group.  
To assess the between-centers variance of effect sizes for VR distraction (relative to control, and non-VR distraction groups) – which may point to ethnic, cultural or other factors related to the effectiveness of this intervention.

We hypothesize, that VR distraction will be more effective than a non-VR distraction (active control group) and treatment as usual (passive control group) in diminishing pain and anxiety

attributes.title: The Longitudinal Association Between Loneliness and Depression: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: A scoping review of research that examined the prospective association between loneliness and depression. Aims broadly include synthesizing findings across studies and characterizing the quality of research in the area.

q1.value: The Longitudinal Association Between Loneliness and Depression: A Scoping Review

q3.value: Loneliness - a sense of social isolation arising from a discrepancy between one's desired and actual relationships - is associated with a host of undesirable biopsychosocial health outcomes that may increase one's risk for early mortality (e.g., Holt-Lunstad, Smith, Baker, Harris, & Stephenson, 2015). It is well established that chronic feelings of loneliness frequently co-occur with depression, however the causal nature of this relationship, as well as various mechanisms, is not well understood. The purpose of this scoping review is to examine the current state of research on the longitudinal (i.e., prospective) association between loneliness and depression. Broadly, we aim to characterize research on the strength and directionality of this association, the time intervals used throughout this research, the populations from which this research has sampled from, mechanisms (i.e., mediators) of this association, the quantitative methods used, and how amenable to open science practices (i.e., preregistering hypotheses, making data publicly available) this research has been thus far.

q4.value: We expect that the majority of research will provide support for the existence of a bidirectional association between loneliness and depression (i.e., that loneliness at T predicts depression at T+1 and that depression at T predicts loneliness at T+1). All other research questions/characterizations of this research are exploratory.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Reviewers will be blind to each other's decisions during the abstract review process.

question.value:
The primary aim of this scoping review is to characterize the state of research on the longitudinal (i.e., prospective) association between loneliness and depression. While we expect to find evidence in support of a reciprocal association, all other research questions are exploratory. In addition to this primary aim, we believe it is important to characterize:
- The time intervals used in this research
- The populations from which this research has sampled
- Mechanisms (i.e., mediators) of the association
- Moderators  of the association
- The quantitative methods used
- Open Science practices (i.e., preregistration, open data) 


We will follow PRISMA-ScR guidelines for this scoping review. First, we will search 5 databases using the following search terms for each (all articles through December 31, 2019):
1. PsycINFO

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (KW lonel*) OR (DE "Loneliness") OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (KW "social isolation") OR (DE "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (KW "social alienation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (KW depress*) OR (DE "Depression (Emotion)") OR (DE "Major Depression")) AND ((MR "Longitudinal Study")  OR (KW "Daily Diary") OR (KW "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (DE "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (KW "Experience Sampling") OR (DE "Diary Measure"))

2. PsycArticles

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (KW lonel*) OR (DE "Loneliness") OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (KW "social isolation") OR (DE "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (KW "social alienation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (KW depress*) OR (DE "Depression (Emotion)") OR (DE "Major Depression")) AND ((MR "Longitudinal Study")  OR (KW "Daily Diary") OR (KW "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (DE "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (KW "Experience Sampling") OR (DE "Diary Measure"))

3. MEDLINE

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (SU lonel*) OR (MH "Loneliness") OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (SU "social isolation") OR (MH "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (SU "social alienation") OR (MH "social alientation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (SU depress*) OR (MH "Depressive Disorder")) AND ((MH "Longitudinal Studies") OR (SU "Daily Diary") OR (SU "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (MH "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (SU "Experience Sampling") OR (MH "Medical Records"))

4. CINAHL Complete

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (SU lonel*) OR (MH "Loneliness") OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (SU "social isolation") OR (MH "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (SU "social alienation") OR (MH "social alientation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (SU depress*) OR (MH "Depression")) AND ((MH "Prospective Studies") OR (MH "Experimental studies") OR (MH "Repeated Measures") OR (MH "Retrospective Design") OR (SU "Daily Diary") OR (SU "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (MH "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (SU "Experience Sampling") OR (MH "Diaries") OR (MH "Daily Logs"))

5. Social Work Abstracts.

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (SU lonel*) OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (SU "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (SU "social alienation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (SU depress*))

Second, a team of one graduate student reviewer and several undergraduate reviewers will conduct the abstract review process, with at least one reviewer per abstract in addition to the graduate student reviewer. If consensus cannot be reached, a PhD Professor of Psychology will determine fit for inclusion/exclusion.  Decisions for exclusion will be noted. Inclusion criteria are:
- Human sample
- Loneliness or synonym (i.e., perceived social isolation; not objective social isolation)
- Depression or depressed mood (not other singular symptom; excluding bipolar disorder)
- Longitudinal method and analysis (including change scores as IV or DV)
- Quantitative analysis
- Not a treatment study
- Published in a peer-reviewed journal
- Manuscript written in English

Third, we will review the full text of articles that did not provide sufficient information within the abstract to make an inclusion/exclusion decision. At least one reviewer in addition to the graduate student reviewer will make this determination.

Fourth, we will conduct a review of all included studies to extract all information relevant to our research question stated above.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Given that our data are published scientific manuscripts through December 31, 2019 they are already in existence. However, the abstract review process has not yet begun.

question.value:
Data will be gathered from the following databases and search terms:

1. PsycINFO

((TI lonel*) OR (AB lonel*) OR (KW lonel*) OR (DE "Loneliness") OR (TI "social isolation") OR (AB "social isolation") OR (KW "social isolation") OR (DE "social isolation") OR (TI "social alienation") OR (AB "social alienation") OR (KW "social alienation")) AND ((TI depress*) OR (AB depress*) OR (KW depress*) OR (DE "Depression (Emotion)") OR (DE "Major Depression")) AND ((MR "Longitudinal Study")  OR (KW "Daily Diary") OR (KW "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (DE "Ecological Momentary Assessment") OR (KW "Experience Sampling") OR (DE "Diary Measure"))

2. PsycArticles

registration_responses.q1: The Longitudinal Association Between Loneliness and Depression: A Scoping Review
registration_responses.q3: Loneliness - a sense of social isolation arising from a discrepancy between one's desired and actual relationships - is associated with a host of undesirable biopsychosocial health outcomes that may increase one's risk for early mortality (e.g., Holt-Lunstad, Smith, Baker, Harris, & Stephenson, 2015). It is well established that chronic feelings of loneliness frequently co-occur with depression, however the causal nature of this relationship, as well as various mechanisms, is not well understood. The purpose of this scoping review is to examine the current state of research on the longitudinal (i.e., prospective) association between loneliness and depression. Broadly, we aim to characterize research on the strength and directionality of this association, the time intervals used throughout this research, the populations from which this research has sampled from, mechanisms (i.e., mediators) of this association, the quantitative methods used, and how amenable to open science practices (i.e., preregistering hypotheses, making data publicly available) this research has been thus far.
registration_responses.q4: We expect that the majority of research will provide support for the existence of a bidirectional association between loneliness and depression (i.e., that loneliness at T predicts depression at T+1 and that depression at T predicts loneliness at T+1). All other research questions/characterizations of this research are exploratory.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The primary aim of this scoping review is to characterize the state of research on the longitudinal (i.e., prospective) association between loneliness and depression. While we expect to find evidence in support of a reciprocal association, all other research questions are exploratory. In addition to this primary aim, we believe it is important to characterize:
- The time intervals used in this research
- The populations from which this research has sampled
- Mechanisms (i.e., mediators) of the association
- Moderators  of the association
- The quantitative methods used
- Open Science practices (i.e., preregistration, open data) 


We will follow PRISMA-ScR guidelines for this scoping review. First, we will search 5 databases using the following search terms for each (all articles through December 31, 2019):

Second, a team of one graduate student reviewer and several undergraduate reviewers will conduct the abstract review process, with at least one reviewer per abstract in addition to the graduate student reviewer. If consensus cannot be reached, a PhD Professor of Psychology will determine fit for inclusion/exclusion.  Decisions for exclusion will be noted. Inclusion criteria are:
- Human sample
- Loneliness or synonym (i.e., perceived social isolation; not objective social isolation)
- Depression or depressed mood (not other singular symptom; excluding bipolar disorder)
- Longitudinal method and analysis (including change scores as IV or DV)
- Quantitative analysis
- Not a treatment study
- Published in a peer-reviewed journal
- Manuscript written in English

Third, we will review the full text of articles that did not provide sufficient information within the abstract to make an inclusion/exclusion decision. At least one reviewer in addition to the graduate student reviewer will make this determination.

Fourth, we will conduct a review of all included studies to extract all information relevant to our research question stated above.

q3.value:
Creativity has grown to be a major driver in the success of organizations (Zhou & Hoever, 2014). This has led to an increasing need to understand the underlying processes that promote creativity. One such process that has been found to strongly predict creativity is a person’s disposition to mindwander (Baird et al., 2012).
	Mindwandering has often been perceived as negative. However, recent research has revealed the potential positive consequences of mindwandering (Smallwood & Schooler, 2015; Smallwood & Andrews-Hana, 2013; Moneyham & Schooler, 2013; Watkins, 2008). Despite these strides in understanding positive mindwandering, discrepancies have emerged between experiencing mindwandering and creativity (Smeekens & Kane, 2016). Some of these discrepancies are differences in self-report versus probing measures (Smeekens & Kane, 2016) and others more related to the content of one’s mind (Tan, Zou, Chen, & Luo, 2016; Hao, Wu, Runco, & Pina, 2015;). 
This paper focuses on the latter through the lens of the content regulation hypothesis. This paper will examine how the emotions experienced during mindwandering may affect creative thinking. Emotions have already been found to influence creative thinking ability (Campion & Levita, 2013; Baas, Dreu, & Nistjad, 2008), but it may also regulate how mindwandering impacts a person’s ability to be creative.
By further understanding how the emotional content of mindwandering effects creativity, researchers may gain a greater understanding of when mindwandering may be positive or negative. This paper will examine creativity and how a new measure of creativity may help in answering this question. I will also discuss the content-regulation-hypothesis of mindwandering and emotions potential relationship. Finally, this paper proposes a correlational study to test the relationship between creativity, mindwandering and positive emotions.

q4.value: Emotions will moderate the relationship between creativity and midnwandering

question.value: For this study, 100 participants will be recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) to test the moderating relationship. Participants recruited through MTurk will be used because it has been found to produce data higher in external validity than other types of sampling methods without much additional cost (Buhrmester, Kwang, & Gosling,  2016). After signing consent forms, participants will take the forward flow free association task with the instructed seed word and proceed to fill out the 19 available lines. Participants will also have to complete 11 RAT problems and will fill out the PANAS-X, the daydreaming frequency scale and the intelligence questions. To control for any ordering effect, order will be randomly assigned in a partial design. counterbalanced PANAS-X and the daydreaming frequency scale will be regressed onto forward flow and RAT scores including an interaction effect.
Forward Flow, RAT, daydreaming scale, verbal skills, critical thinking and matrices tasks , emotions on the PANAS-X scale
